headline: THE OLD YEAR AND THE NEW.
leadPara: The year 1912 has been notable for agitation and unsettlement, for things begun but not yet completed, perhaps never to be completed, rather than for determinations actually reached. The most disturbing agitation of the year was doubtless that in which Mr. ROOSEVELT was the prime mover, for his Progressive Party formulated a programme of action that aimed at grave changes in the structure of our Government.

headline: TAFT INVITES ALL. BOLTERS TO RETURN; Proud Even in Defeat That His Candidacy Saved the Country from Chaos and Anarchy.

headline: Owing to the Exceptionally Short Season This Year the Six Weeks Between Now and Lent Will be Marked with an Unusual Amount of Social Activity.

In fact, according to the church calendar, ninety-five years will elapse before another season of such limited measure rolls around.

headline: SHIP SINKS WITH 33.; Oil Tank Ship Rosecrans Is Wrecked In Gale on the Pacific Coast.
leadPara: ASTORIA, Ore., Jan. 7. -- The oil tank steamship Rosecrans, Capt. L.F. Johnson, from Monterey, Cal., bound for Portland, Ore., ran aground early to-day on Peacock Spit, while striving to reach the Columbia River, during a fifty-mile gale, and was lost, with thirty-three members of her crew of thirty-seven. One survivor of the wreck, it was reported to-night, had reached safety at Tioga, Wash., six miles from the scene of the wreck.

headline: DEAL WITH WILSON IN SENATORIAL FIGHT; Progressives to be Chosen in Maine and New Hampshire and Will Support Him.

leadPara: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The first move of the Progressive Party toward keeping up a permanent party organization was made to-day when headquarters were opened in both New York and Washington. This action is intended to serve as notice that the Progressive Party has come to stay, that it will not treat with the Republicans and that it intends to put a separate National party ballot in the field in 1916.
abstract: opens headquarters in New York and Washington

headline: BAR APPROVES TAFT CANAL TOLLS STAND; State Association Rejects Committee Resolution Asking Him to Accept Arbitration.
leadPara: UTICA, Jan. 24. -- The State Bar Association, in its thirty-sixth annual meeting to-day, voted approval of President Taft's position in regard to the Panama Canal tolls. It rejected the majority report of its Committee on International Arbitration presented by Everett F. Wheeler. A minority report submitted by Charles Henry Butler was more favorable to the President's stand, but was similar in thought, to the other.
abstract: New York State Bar Association approves Pres. Taft's stand

leadPara: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The election of Willard Saulsbury, Democratic National Committeeman from Delaware, to represent that State in the United States Senate, raises the certain Democratic net majority in that body to two for the coming extraordinary session. This majority will rise to four next year during the regular session, when the Democratic Legislature of Maryland elects a successor to William H. Jackson, now serving by appointment of the Republican Governor.

headline: GOMPERS WON'T HAVE FORCED ARBITRATION; Tells National Civic Federation Labor Would Fight Before It Would Accept It.
leadPara: Heated arguments marked the closing sessions of the National Civic Federation at the Hotel Astor yesterday. Debates were waged on questions of compulsory arbitration of industrial disputes, the minimum wage laws, the protocol in the cloak industry, and the strike now on in the men's garment industry. The labor representatives who had remained remarkably quiet at Tuesday's session came strongly to the front in yesterday's discussions. They were headed by Samuel Gompers.
abstract: argues against compulsory arbitration of labor strikes at National Civic Federation Meeting

headline: DEMOCRATS MAY GET ILLINOIS SENATOR; Expected as a Result of Compromise by Which Speakership Deadlock Is Broken.
leadPara: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 29. -- William McKinley of Chicago, serving his first term, was elected Speaker of the House of Representatives to-day on the seventy-sixth ballot, receiving 83 votes, six more than the Constitutional majority.

headline: DROPS DARTMOUTH GAME.; Harvard Finds Football Schedule Too Hard with Hanoverians on It.
leadPara: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29. -- When the Harvard football schedule for 1913 appears it will contain no date for a game between Harvard and Dartmouth. The schedule, which has been drawn up by the Football Committee, still has to be ratified by the Athletic Committee of the university, but there is no question about the Athletic Committee's accepting the suggestions of the football men.
abstract: Dartmouth game dropped

headline: TOPICS IN WALL STREET.

headline: BRAYAN, CABINET HEAD, IF HE WANTS PLACE; Gov. Wilson Said to Have Sent Col. House to Offer Him Portfolio of Secretary of State.
leadPara: TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- There is no longer any question that William J. Bryan will be the next Secretary of State if he cares to accept the place. There is no question, either, that from the very first Mr. Bryan has been the man whom Gov. Wilson wished to appoint. It is quite probable that he had the idea in mind long before election day.

headline: THEFT OF STATE'S STAMPS.; Former Janitor of State Capitol Held in Bail for Grand Jury.
leadPara: ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- John H. Berard of Highland Falls, former janitor of the Capitol in this city, was arraigned before County Judge Atkinson to-day on a charge of stealing $60 worth of stamps from the State Controller's office. He was held for the action of the Grand Jury and gave ball in the sum of $3,000.

headline: MOST REMARKABLE GIRLS' SCHOOL IN THE WORLD

headline: NEW YORK'S PUBLIC SCHOOLS ARE TOO CUT AND DRIED; Too Much System, Which Transforms Our Educational Scheme Into Something Like a Factory for Making Human Duplicates, Says Thomas W. Churchill, Probable New President of the Board of Education.

headline: BIG FUND RAISED FOR THE HEBREW UNION COLLEGE; This, With the Dedication of the New Buildings at Cincinnati, Crowns a Half Century of Heroic Work by Its Founder, the Late Rev. Dr. Isaac M. Wise.

headline: NO DEAL TO ELECT SHERMAN.; Plan Discovered Which Would Mean Defeat for Senate of Col. J.H. Lewis.

headline: IN NEW ZEALAND; Mr. Lusk's Account of a Government Experiment

It has the largest national debt in proportion to its population of any country in the world. The per capita of its wealth tops that of all other nations. headline: HAS DR. FRIEDMANN REALLY FOUND A TUBERCULOSIS CURE?; The Known Facts in This Remarkable Medical Mystery Are Here Carefully Analyzed by an Expert of National Reputation, and Approved by Two World-Wide Authorities on the Disease.

headline: LIQUOR BILL VETO REJECTED BY SENATE; President Returned It as Unconstitutional, but His Objections Were Overruled.

headline: INAUGURAL SPEECH DELIGHTS GERMANS; The Berlin Tageblatt Says President Wilson Has Made a Splendid Beginning.

headline: A PARALLEL.

They were peaceable men, modest, loyal, devoted to the principles of our institutions, able to perceive the need of applying them to changing conditions, but firmly desirous that they should not be overthrown or undermined.

headline: GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY.; To Debate with Cornell on the Recall of Judicial Decisions.

headline: DIVORCE CHANGES TO AID POPULATION; French Parliament Asked to Make Progressive Paralysis a Ground for Legal Separation.
leadPara: PARIS, March 29. -- Agitation is on spot here to obtain a wider application of the French divorce laws. It is thought by a large number of people an altogether illogical defect in the law that incurable madness or disease on the part of the one married partner does not give the other sufficient ground for dissolution of the union, especially in the case of the terrible affliction known as general progressive paralysis.

headline: MICHIGAN BURIES SUFFRAGE.; Women's Amendment Swamped -- Republicans Claim State Victory.
leadPara: DETROIT, April 8. -- Woman suffrage met a staggering defeat at yesterday's election in Michigan. Some of the manufacturers who have been over the ground have brought, or sent back accounts of great enthusiasm.

headline: REPRIEVE FOR LINGLEY.; Respite of Three Weeks for Murderer Who Was to Die To-morrow.
leadPara: ALBANY, April 12. -- After consultation with Chief Judge Cullen of the Court of Appeals, Gov. Sulzer, before leaving for New York to-day, granted a three weeks reprieve to William Lingley, sentenced to be put to death at Sing Sing Prison on Monday next. The Governor said last Wednesday that after a careful examination of the evidence in the case he had decided there was no ground for interference.
abstract: held for cashing of check

headline: GROCERS TURN TO MOTOR WAGONS NOW; More Than $5,500,000 Is Invested by Them in Newer Form of Transportation.
leadPara: The cost of living to the people of the United States is at least $1,200,000,000 more than it should be, and this loss is directly attributable to the present wasteful methods of handling and distributing food products, according to Henry Farmington in an article to appear in Power Wagon.

headline: NEW REGIME TARGET FOR GRIDIRON JESTS; Washington Club Breaks Bread with Democrats and Jokes Them While They Eat.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, April 12. -- President Wilson attended his first Gridiron Club entertainment to-night. It was the quadrennial Spring dinner of this organization of Washington newspaper correspondents, given after the incoming of each new National Administration. About 250 guests and members sat at the tables, arranged in the form of a gridiron, in the banquet hall of the New Willard Hotel, and the fun was kept going until midnight.
abstract: Attends dinner of Gridiron Club

headline: GOOD ROADS NOW TO WASHINGTON, D.C.; Improvement Work Has Been Completed Over Most of the Route from This City.
leadPara: Automobilists making the trip between New York and Washington will no longer find it necessary to follow the route by way of Lancaster, York, Hanover, and Littletown. A more direct way between Philadelphia and Baltimore, via Wilmington, is available. This is along the Delaware River, through Darby, Eddystone, Chester, Brandywine Centre, and several other small towns.

headline: NOTED MEN WHO KNEW HIM LAUD THE MANY-SIDED MORGAN; Tributes Which Show Him Great Not Only as a Financier but as Patriot, Citizen, Churchman, Philanthropist, Art Collector, and Man.
leadPara: IN the worldwide outburst of encomium on J. Pierpont Morgan, a universal eulogy which, instead of dying out in a day or two, has grown in volume since his death, one thing stands clearer-cut than any other. It is the great variety of the tributes, and the resultant revelation of the many-sideness of Morgan's greatness.

headline: Beautifying New York Discussed by Municipal Art Society. A City Planning Commission.

headline: "WITH FOLDED ARMS."

headline: TARIFF BILL PROOF AGAINST ASSAULT; House Democrats Stand Firm in Allowing Only Verbal Changes Proposed by Committee.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Republican and Progressive Party members of the House to-day abandoned all hope of amending the Underwood Tariff bill. They worked hard to change the rates in the earlier schedules of the measure, covering chemicals, oils, paints, earthenware and glassware, steel and metals, offering many amendments and heckling the Democratic leaders with charges that the bill was illogical, unscientific and hobble-skirted.

leadPara: ALBANY, April 30. -- Gov. Sulzer's Direct Nominations bill suffered an overwhelming defeat in the Senate to-day. Eight votes, two of which were cast by Republicans, were all that the advocates of the bill could muster in the upper House. Forty-two votes were cast against it.

headline: MICHIGAN LEADS IN MIDWEST ROADS; Has System of Rewards for Road Work Which Acts Well -- How Other States Line Up.

Chapin is Chairman. The Prairie and Rocky Mountain States and the South are waking up, but have not accomplished much in their present legislative sessions.

headline: Buildings of the University of New Mexico Reproductions of the Ancient Indian Pueblo Structures.
leadPara: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., May 3. -- New Mexico has given to the University of New Mexico buildings at Albuquerque of a form and distinction not to be found in university buildings elsewhere in the United States. They are a reproduction of the ancient Indian pueblo, peculiar to the primitive tribes of New Mexico and adjoining regions.

headline: REFORMED RABBIS TO MEET; Conference of Eastern Council Opens To-day at Temple Emanu-El.
leadPara: The half yearly conference of the Eastern Council of Reformed Rabbis will begin to-day at the Temple Emanu-El. About forty rabbis from other cities will be present at the gathering, which has as its purpose the promotion of the cause of modren progressive Judaism. At the session this afternoon Dr. Nathaniel Sehmidt, Professor of Old Testament Literature at Cornell, will speak on "The Interest to Modern Judaism of an Independent Syria."

headline: HALT TO PARTISAN DEBATE.; Underwood Rebukes Squabbling Opponents During Tariff Discussion.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 5. -- A halt to personal and partisan repartee during consideration of the tariff measure was called to-day by House Leader Underwood. After a heated interchange by Victor Murdock of Kansas, the third party leader, Mr. Mann of Illinois, the Republican leader, and W.E. Humphrey, a Republican from Washington, Mr. Underwood served notice that members must confine their remarks to the tariff.

headline: SULZER WARNS ALL STATE BOND BUYERS; Special Session Will Repeal Frawley Laws and Take Away "Advantage."

headline: PROGRESSIVES INCORPORATE.; Organization Is to Maintain Party's Principles in This State.
leadPara: ALBANY, May 7. -- The New York Progressive Association, a membership corporation, with principal office at 32 Washington Square West, New York City, filed its certificate with the Secretary of State to-day. Its field is New York State and its object is "to maintain the principles of the said party by all legal means."

headline: LIKENS NEW HAVEN TO WILDCAT SCHEME; Road's Affairs Managed in an Appallingly Reckless Manner, Says Brandeis.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, May 7. -- In a speech before the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, Louis D. Brandeis made charges of reckless extravagance and maladministration against the officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford and the Boston Maine railroads. He compared the management to that of a wildcat mining scheme, and said the state of affairs was induced by a spirit of monopolization and aggrandizement.

headline: LATEST DEALINGS IN THE REALTY FIELD; Block Front on Upper Broadway Leased to New Corporation for Sixty-three Years.

leadPara: The Bull Moose Party virtually started its local municipal campaign last night at a dinner conference at the Star Casino, 107th Street and Lexington Avenue. Some 2,500 party men applauded the presentation of a platform which declared among other things for the recall of members of the Board of Estimate, the referendum as applied to franchises, municipal ownership of public utilities, the establishment of a municipal ice plant, and cheaper electric lighting and telephone service.

headline: REPUBLICANS PLAN REFORM CONVENTION; Leaders Feel One Is Necessary This Summer -- Purge Party of Evils, Says Hadley.

Hadley of Missouri at the Republican conference at the Congress Hotel, was dependent on establishing in the minds of the people the honest belief that the evils and practices which brought disruption had been discarded and wholly removed.

headline: HARVESTER TRADE HAS BANNER YEAR; International Company's Net Profits $16,395,597 in 1912, Says Its Report.

headline: OLD GUARD DECIDES AGAINST CONVENTION; Conservative Republicans Oppose Any Harmony with Progressive Faction Yet.

leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Neither President Wilson nor the Democratic managers of the two branches of Congress could estimate to-night what effect the Senate's remarkable "lobby investigation" is to have upon the progress of the Tariff bill, the currency reform plan, or other business of Congress.

headline: JEWISH SEMINARY GRADUATES RABBIS; Eleven Receive Degrees at Exercises Which Also Mark Tenth Anniversary.
leadPara: Eleven students of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America became rabbis yesterday afternoon at the graduating exercises in Aeolian Hall, when Dr. Solomon Schechter, the President of the seminary, conferred the degrees. The services marked the tenth anniversary of the seminary's reorganization.
abstract: Graduating exercises; address by Dr. Schechter

headline: THE BASIS OF PEACE.
leadPara: The tide of hopeful feeling throughout Europe has run so strong and high during the past fortnight in connection with the celebration of the wedding of the German Emperor's daughter, that a certain reaction is pretty sure to follow. Yet there is much evidence that this feeling was justified, both by the celebration and the utterances of which it was the occasion and by the experience of the last six months.
abstract: Peace, basis of, editorial

headline: UPHOLDS RIGHT OF STATE TO FIX RAILROAD RATES; Supreme Court Unanimous in Supporting Minnesota's Long-Fought Maximum Law.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Supreme Court of the United States in a unanimous decision to-day sustained the right of the States to fix intra-State rates on inter-State railroads, even where this control indirectly affected inter-State commerce. The court made it plain, however, that where State control influenced conditions of commerce outside the State borders, the control of the State lasted only until Congress provided otherwise.
abstract: Minnesota's right to fix railroad rates upheld

headline: PARTY RULE SAFE, ASSERTS ROOSEVELT; Primary Bill, He Tells Buffalo Audience, Is Aimed at Dishonest Bosses.
leadPara: BUFFALO, June 10. -- Col. Theodore Roosevelt opened his campaign for direct primaries in this city to-night. His reception was cordial, and he appeared mightily pleased from the time he arrived here late this afternoon until the meeting closed. The meeting had been heralded as non-partisan, but the arrangements were in the hands of Chauncey J. Hamlin, local leader of the Bull Moose clan.
abstract: speech in Buffalo

headline: NO WILSON CANDIDATE YET.; Report Naming Garrison for Jersey Governor Not Confirmed.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The great interest felt in New Jersey over the forthcoming contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination has its echoes among prominent Democrats from that State in Washington. Rumors relating to the attitude of the President in the matter have caused some gossip, although, in the opinion of those New Jersey men here who are best informed, it is too early to indulge in speculation as to the President's ultimate course.
abstract: has not declared choice for Gubernatorial candidate

headline: TO INVESTIGATE FRISCO.; Senate Adopts Resolution for Inquiry into Receivership.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 10. -- In a way almost perfunctory the Senate adopted to-day a resolution presented by Senator Kenyon of Iowa last Thursday calling on the Inter-State Commerce Commission to investigate and report to the Senate all the facts and circumstances concerning the purchase of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad by the St. Louis San Francisco Railroad Company.
abstract: resolution adopted

headline: ILLINOIS VOTES SUFFRAGE.; House Passes Senate Bill -- Motion to Reconsider It.

headline: TREASURY OFFERS EMERGENCY NOTES; Secretary McAdoo Announces Readiness to Issue Circulation Under Aldrich-Vreeland Act.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 11. -- To assure the country that the Federal Administration stood ready to give all the assistance within its authority to ease the financial situation should any emergency arise, the Secretary of the Treasury announced to-night that he would not hesitate to issue emergency currency up to the legal limit to National banks or currency associations making application to him.
abstract: Provides for issue of emergency notes by U. S.; history of Act, contents

headline: ROOSEVELT WITH SULZER.; Speaks at Rochester, Where Governor Renews Threats.
leadPara: ROCHESTER, June 11. -- Almost 8,000 persons crowded the largest auditorium in the city and the two biggest theatres to-night to hear Col. Theodore Roosevelt and Gov. William Sulzer, with other Progressives and Democrats, advocate the Governor's primary reform measures.
abstract: assails primary bill in speech at West Side Independent Club

headline: NEW YORK BANKERS FETED IN OTTAWA; Guests of Dominion at Banquet After Opening Their Convention.
leadPara: OTTAWA, June 12. -- International peace is the watchword of the New York State Bankers' Association, whose convention opened here to-day in the Chateau Laurier. Peace was the keynote of the addresses made in the convention in the day and at the banquet given for the delegates to-night by the Dominion Government.
abstract: address at convention of N. Y. State Bankers' Assoc.

headline: TOBACCO TAX SCHEME DEAD; Wilson Never Gave McReynolds Idea More Than 3 Minutes' Thought
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Although those in a position to know the facts are guarded in their statements, practically no doubt remains that the plan of Attorney General McReynolds to curtail the production of the companies that formerly composed the Tobacco Trust by imposing a "progressive excise tax" on their output beyond a fixed amount has been abandoned.
abstract: tax plan dead; never considered by Pres. Wilson

headline: CHICAGO WOMEN IN VICTORY MARCH; Suffragists Plan Big Celebration To-day in Honor of Their Springfield Lobby.
leadPara: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 12. -- The only influence employed by the women to secure the passage of suffrage bill in Illinois was the influence of quiet, persistent, educational work.
abstract: Mrs. Grace W. Trout tells how suffrage campaign was won; celebration planned in Chicago

headline: ALMOST IN A RIOT SUPPORTING SULZER; Yonkers Hisses and Boos Senator Healy Off the Stage, Breaking Up Meeting.
leadPara: WHITE PLAINS, June 13. -- After addressing audiences at Yonkers and New Rochelle, Gov. Sulzer wound up a whirlwind tour of Westchester County in the interest of his Direct Nominations bill with a speech before a crowded meeting here.
abstract: speaks in Yonkers, assailing Sen. Healy, meeting is broken up when Senator tries to reply

headline: ART AT HOME AND ABROAD; Studios to be Established Here in Which Art Students May Acquire Craftsmanship in Decorative Work
leadPara: IT is news and good news for the friends of decorative art that studios are to he established in which young artists can receive the careful and sustained training that will permit them to become good craftsmen as mural decorators. The lack of competent craftsmanship among art students is the stumbling block in the way of mural decoration in this country.

headline: POSTHUMOUS BOOK BY FERRER REVEALS HIS IDEALS; Only Volume Written by the Founder of the Modern School in Spain Tells for the First Time the Origin of the System of Education for Which He Was Executed.
leadPara: FRANCISCO FERRER Y GUARDIA was shot in the trenches of the Montjuich Fortress at Barcelona on Oct. 12, 1909. Instantly there was an uproar in the world of thinking men and women. Conservative opinion accepted and approved the decision of the military council that had found him guilty of "being the head of the insurrection" which had, a few months before, plunged the Province of Barcelona into civil war.

headline: STANDARDIZING MARY---A DOMESTIC CATASTROPHE
leadPara: IT as all my fault an when I come to think it over, I don't blame her if she never comes back, and I never had so good a girl as Mary, either."

headline: MISSOURI'S LIVELY FIGHT AGAINST THE INSURANCE TRUST; The Latter Is Making a Strenuous Resistance Against Laws Compelling It to Make Profits, Thus Presenting a Situation That Is a Novelty in Anglo-Saxon Legislation.
leadPara: ON Monday last Insurance Commissioner Revell issued citations against the insurance companies of Missouri requiring them to show cause on Thursday next why their licenses should not be revoked. This is the latest but not the last chapter in a battle of wits between legislators and men of business which abounds with surprises, and is a novelty in that it seeks to compel men of business to make a profit against their strenuous resistance.

headline: ASSAULT ON BOSSES AS SULZER WINDS UP; Names Murphy and Likens Him to Tweed -- Hearst Calls Him Charles Finance Murphy.
leadPara: Gov. Sulzer wound up his campaign for direct primaries by addressing three overflow meetings in the city last night, two in Brooklyn and the final one at Cooper Union. The latter place was crowded to the doors, and the Governor got a rousing reception. He denounced the political bosses, and called Charles F. Murphy by name, likening him to Boss Tweed.
abstract: Brings suit against Ben. F. Hardesty

headline: SEE POLITICAL RULE LEAVE MANHATTAN; Outlying Boroughs Will Have Balance of Power in Designating Conventions.
leadPara: With what undoubtedly will prove to be one of the most important and interesting municipal campaigns in the history of this city approaching, the sceptre of control in the party councils in which candidates for the city ticket are to be nominated is passing from the Borough of Manhattan.

headline: ORDER BEFORE INDEPENDENCE.
leadPara: We think that the advocates of independence for the Philippine Islands make a serious error in committing themselves unreservedly to the scheme introduced in the last Congress, and urged in this, fixing a definite date at which complete independence shall be established.
abstract: order before independence, editorial

headline: CURRENCY BILL OUT; RESERVE BANK PLAN; Fifteen Associations to be Created, Composed of National and State Banks.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 15. -- With the completion of the final tentative draft of the proposed banking and currency measure which Senator Owen and Representative Glass, as the respective Chairmen of the Senate and House Banking and Currency Committees, have been preparing in co-operation with Secretary McAdoo of the Treasury, THE NEW YORK TIMES presents herewith an accurate outline of its essential features.
abstract: outline of first tentative draft completed by committee, fifteen reserve associations, composed of National and State banks planned

headline: FITZPATRICK WON'T MEDDLE.; Erie Boss Rejects Plea of Sulzer Committee.
leadPara: BUFFALO, June 16. -- William H. Fitzpatrick, Chairman of the Erie County Democratic Committee, declined today to influence the votes of the Democratic legislators from Erie County in favor of Gov. Sulzer's Direct Primary bill, when called upon by a citizens' committee, authorized at the recent Sulzer mass meeting and appointed by Chauncey J. Hamlin, Chairman of the Progressive County Committee.
abstract: will not influence Democratic votes from Erie County in favor of Gov. Sulzer's Direct Primary bill

headline: 6,000 YALE ALUMNI IN STRIKING PARADE; Prof. Taft Marches with Younger Graduates in Queer Togs at Yale-Harvard Ball Game.
leadPara: NEW HAVEN, June 17. -- Yale's biggest alumni outpouring in university history took place during to-day's graduate day exercises of the commencement programme. Easily 6,000 alumni marched to Yale Field for the spectacular parade incident to the Yale-Harvard baseball game.
abstract: Alumni assemble for commencement; scholarship honors announced

headline: FUSION SPLITS ON WHITMAN'S NAME; Republicans Want Him, but Bull Moose Would Rather Have an Anti-Machine Man.

Whitman is the Mayoralty candidate of the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred and Seven, which is arranging fusion against Tammany.

headline: URGES TAX ON BIG TRUSTS.; Proposal by Hitchcock in Addition to His Tobacco Tax Plan.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 17. -- A proposal to tax certain big manufacturing, concerns so that it would be impossible for them to produce profitably more than one-fourth of their respective lines of manufacture was presented to the Senate to-day by Senator Hitchcock of Nebraska.
abstract: amendment providing for taxing of production of big manufacturing concerns presented by Sen. Hitchcock; he will continue to press tobacco tax amendment

headline: SULZER IS SILENT ON MURPHY VISIT; Denounces McCabe in Albany Rally Speech, but Ignores Story of Calls on Boss.
leadPara: ALBANY, June 17. -- Before a large crowd attracted to the well-advertised direct primaries rally in Harmanus Bleecker Hall to-night, Gov. Sulzer replied, after a fashion, to the statement issued yesterday by Patrick E. McCabe, the Albany County boss.
abstract: corroborates McCabe's statements in reference to Gov. Sulzer's visits

headline: OUR BRAZILIAN VISITOR.
leadPara: It is not without a certain significance that the Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, now returning Mr. ROOT'S visit, made seven years since, should bear the very German name of MUELLER. The reception accorded to him by the Federal Government and by New York is cordial, as it should be from sentiment and from interest.
abstract: trade relations, editorial

headline: HOWLANDS RESIGN FROM THE OUTLOOK; Publisher Quits to Join The Independent, and His Sons Follow Him.
leadPara: William B. Howland has resigned as Vice President and publisher of The Outlook after twenty-three years' service. He has retained his share in the ownership of that publication and has purchased a large interest in The Independent, of which he will be an official.

headline: SENATORS TO SIFT LOVETT CHARGES; Unanimous Vote to Investigate Alleged Blackmail Efforts in Pacifics' Dissolution Plan.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 18. -- After a brief debate and without a dissenting vote, the Senate directed the Lobby Committee this afternoon to investigate charges of blackmail made yesterday by ex-Judge Robert S. Lovett, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, in connection with the settlement of the dissolution of the Union Pacific-Southern Pacific merger.
abstract: charges to be investigated by Senate Lobby Committee; McReynolds may not approve exchange

headline: ROOSEVELT ASSURES WHITMAN SUPPORT; No Announcement Yet, but One Is Expected to Follow a Late Oyster Bay Conference.
leadPara: District Attorney Charles S. Whitman went to Oyster Bay yesterday and had a long conference with Col. Roosevelt. It was assumed to be all about Mr. Whitman's chances for the Mayoralty nomination. Upon his return to New York Mr. Whitman would say nothing of his conversation with the Colonel, but it was understood that the Colonel assured him that he would have the support of the Progressives this Fall.

headline: NONE BUT WHITMAN SUITS REPUBLICANS; County Committee Unanimous in Presenting His Name to Fusion Committee.
leadPara: In a meeting that boiled over with enthusiasm the Republican County Committee went on record last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum as unanimously in favor of District Attorney Charles S. Whitman as a candidate for Mayor. It was the largest meeting the committee had held in years, about 500 of the 600 members being present.
abstract: urges Mr. Whitman for Mayoralty candidate

headline: SUPPORTS GOV. SULZER.; Prof. Hayes Says Direct Primary Bill Meets a Condition.
leadPara: Charles E. Hughes, a Republican Governor, recognized that, whatever the theoretical claims that if the people were sufficiently devoted to polities they could work their will through a delegate system for the choice of candidates, as a fact the securing of continued and concerted popular action was so difficult that the bosses could scarcely be dislodged for long without direct primaries.
abstract: Sulzer bill praised by Alfred Hayes, Jr.

headline: AUSTRALIA LOOKS FOR TRADE HERE; Two Leading Men from There Say Our Free Wool Is Going to Help Them and Us, Too.

McEnnally of Sydney, who arrived at the Imperial yesterday. Mr. Walker is manager of Challicum Station, a big sheep and cattle raising ranch, and a stockholder in the company which owns it, and Mr. McEnnally is a merchant, who imports lumber and fruit.

headline: BANKS EXPLAIN ABOUT CURRENCY; Simple Lessons in Finance in Answer to the 33 Questions Asked by the Senate.
leadPara: The answers of the Currency Commission of the American Bankers' Association to the questions asked by a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency as to the defects of the present banking and currency system, and the changes needed, were made public yesterday. The answers were prepared at the sessions of the Currency Commission held in Atlantic City on Wednesday and Thursday, and constitute a complete discussion of the problems to be solved.

headline: "PERIALISM IS DRAGGING BACK AMERICA IDEALIM"
leadPara: THAT we Americans are an idealistic, progressive people hampered and dragged back by an imperialistic, retrogressive Government, is the opinion of the famous publicist and peace advocate, Baron d'Estournelles de Constant, who has visited us four times in the interests of international peace and traveled over our country from ocean to ocean.

headline: GERMANY EXCITED OVER BANNED PLAY; Clerical Influences Believed to Have Caused Suppression of Hauptmann's Epic.
leadPara: BERLIN, June 22. -- Political and intellectual Germany has not for years been so torn asunder as at the present moment over the action of the City of Breslau in banning Gerhart Hauptmann's epic centenary drama on the ground of its alleged unpatriotic tendencies.

leadPara: ALBANY, June 23. -- While an eleventh-hour spectacular demonstration in support of the Sulzer Direct Nominations bill was being staged at the Capitol to-day, Gov. headline: HENRY R. TOWNE.

TOWNE of the President's office, which he has held since 1908. headline: BOY SHOOTS IN COURT.; Tries to Kill Attorneys and Judge When Held as Highwayman.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Judge, lawyers, policemen, and spectators were sent scurrying to cover in the Criminal Court here late to-day when Ray M. Stewart, aged is fired three wild shots in an attempt to "shoot up" the court. At the first shot, Justice Wendall P. Stafford disappeared beneath his desk, and out in the courtroom there was a wild scramble for places of safety.

Towne, deposed editor of The Scranton Tribune-Republican and The Scranton Truth, morning and evening papers respectively, would start a new paper, which will be known as The Dally News and will appear on or about July 4.

leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 27. -- All the correspondence and other papers in the possession of Attorney General McReynolds relating to his action in postponing the trials of Caminetti and Diggs, charged with violating the white slave law, and Bruce and Smith, charged with conspiracy to defraud the customs revenues, will be sent to the House to-morrow, according to announcement made this evening by that official, who will not wait for action by the House.

headline: HUERTA IN COLLECTOR FIGHT; Objection to Possible Texas Appointment Astonishes Washington.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Huerta Government of Mexico has protested to the United States Government against the suggested appointment by President Wilson of Frank Rabb of Brownsville as Collector of Customs on the lower Rio Grande. The cause of this unusual procedure of a foreign Government protesting against a possible appointment by this Government to a domestic office has not been learned.

headline: HOW THE WORK OF FINISHING NEW YORK IS GETTING ALONG; "It Will Be a Fine Town When It's Done," We Say, But We Don't Realize How Much Is Being Accomplished Toward Getting It Done.
leadPara: IT'S an old saying that New York will be a fine city when it is finished, but few who say it realize how far the city has gone in laying down lines on which its future must develop and how many great works are now under way which will be sufficient for its needs for years to come.

headline: "THE MADISON IDEA" MAY SOLVE BIG PROBLEMS OF CITIES; Mayor Blankenburg of Philadelphia, Who Headed a Pilgrimage of That City's Officials and Leaders of Affairs "to Go to School" at the University of Wisconsin, Believes the Ideals Taught There Will Be of Great Aid to the Nation.
leadPara: THE "Wisconsin Idea," as expressed at Madison, capital of the State and seat of Wisconsin University, has been gaining fame for several years as one of the most interesting experiments in civic government ever known in the United States.

headline: PEANUT SHORTAGE COMING.; Consumption Is Increasing Too Rapidly for Increase in Crops.
leadPara: Although peanut raising has advanced greatly in recent years, the demand for peanuts has increased even faster, and dealers say that there is danger of a complete exhaustion of the present supply before this year's crop is harvested. In other years, when the domestic crop has been short, peanuts have been imported from Spain. Recent cable advices, however, have been to the effect that Spain has no peanuts to export this year.

headline: PLEADS FOR LIFE FOR REPUBLICANS; Ex-Gov. Hadley of Missouri Tells New Jersey the Party Should Not Die.
leadPara: TRENTON, N.J., June 28. -- A State Republican rally, called by the Republican County Chairmen's Association as a prelude to the coming State campaign, attracted about 500 men and a handful of women to the Broad Street Theatre here this afternoon to hear ex-Gov. Hadley of Missouri and ex-Gov. E.C. Stokes of New Jersey speak.
abstract: pleads for life of Republican Party; declares disaster was due to abuse of power

headline: MONTCLAIR JOYOUS IN NEW TERMINAL; Lackawanna and Other Railroad Officials Hear Praise for Company on Opening Day.

abstract: Montclair terminal opened

headline: GLYNN GOVERNOR, SAYS CARMODY; Attorney General, Defining "Impeachment,'' Holds It Automatically Put Sulzer Out.
leadPara: ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- In an opinion handed down to-night in response to a communication from Secretary of State Mitchell May, Attorney General Carmody declares Lieut. Gov. Martin H. Glynn is Acting Governor of the State of New York, pending the trial of the impeachment lodged against William Sulzer as Governor.
abstract: held to be Acting Governor by Attorney General Carmody

headline: PROGRESSIVES IN TILT.; Treachery Charge Almost Starts Fight at Westchester Meeting.
leadPara: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- At the meeting of the Vestchester County Progressive Committee held to-night for the purpose of designating candidates to make the run for the various offices at the pr. tmaries there was almost a fee-for-all fight when one of the committee openly charged that the committee had sold out to the Democratic leader of the eoufty.
abstract: Joseph E. Corrigan seeks nomination

headline: THE CHANNEL TUNNEL AGAIN.
abstract: arguments for and against it, editorial

headline: FUSION RATIFIED BY REPUBLICANS; Rough Session of Committee Ends in Indorsing the Whole Ticket.
leadPara: At a riotous meeting of their City Designating Committee, held at the Murray Hill Lyceum, Third Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, last night, the Republicans voted to indorse the city ticket nominated by the Fusion Committee of 107. The ticket is John Purroy Mitchel for Mayor, William A. Prendergast for Controller, and George McAneny for President of the Board of Aldermen.
abstract: Republicans vote to indorse ticket at stormy meeting

headline: DEMOCRATS RALLY FOR FREE SUGAR; Republican Amendments Defeated by a Solid Party Vote, Except for the Louisianans.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- President Wilson's programme for free sugar in 1916 won in the Senate to-day, when Democrats rallied to the support of the tariff bill and defeated all amendments to the sugar schedule. With all but Senators Ransdell and Thornton of Louisiana standing firm for the Administration measure, the Democrats defeated the Bristow amendment for a compromise duty, the Norris amendment against free sugar, and the Gallinger amendment against free maple sugar.
abstract: Pres. Wilson's programme for free sugar in 1916 wins; Republican amendments defeated; Dutch standard color test abolished

headline: FOSS NOT ON G.O.P. TICKET.
abstract: no papers filed for Gov. Foss; Col. Benton and A. P. Gardner nominated by Republicans; D. I. Walsh and C. S. Bird by Democrats and Progressives

headline: STOKES A CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR AGAIN; Ex-Governor of New Jersey Willing to Run "if the People Want Him."
leadPara: TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Saying that he is not personally ambitious, but that he deems it his duty to see if it is the wish of the rank and file of the party that he should lead its fortunes, ex-Gov. Edward Casper Stokes announced himself to-day as a candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.
abstract: will be a candidate for Republican gubernatorial nomination of N. J.

headline: Favor Seating of Progressive.
abstract: Favors seating W. J. MacDonald, Progressive

headline: TAMMANY LEADERS COMING TO GAYNOR; Opposition Dying Out and He Is Generally Accepted as Its Candidate.
leadPara: With the question of the indorsement of the Fusion city ticket by the Republicans and Progressives out of the way, Tammany began yesterday to put the finishing touches to its municipal slate for presentation to the Democratic City Designating Committee, which will meet at Terrace Garden on Saturday afternoon.
abstract: William M. Wadhams wanted for Supreme Court Justice

headline: TO CHARGE SULZER WITH USURPATION; Accusation Based on Retention of Office to be Added to Articles of Impeachment.
leadPara: ALBANY, Aug. 20. -- A formal charge of usurpation will be lodged against William Sulzer with the High Court of Impeachment when that tribunal meets here on Sept. 18. This became known after a meeting of the Trustees of Public Buildings held at noon to-day, at which quarters were officially assigned to acting Gov. Martin H. Glynn from which to direct the affairs of the State.
abstract: will be charged with usurpation; Glynn issues proclamation

headline: FINDS US IGNORANT OF THE REAL RUSSIA; De Bernoff, Here to Lecture, Says We Have Not Received Intelligent Classes.
leadPara: Michael de Bernoff, Russian lecturer and journalist, finished yesterday his first week in New York, in which he has oriented himself. Having got his bearings, so to speak, Mr. de Bernoff consented to give some of his impressions. One is, that American women very much resemble those of Russia.
abstract: will lecture in America on Russia

headline: FUSIONIST REVISION FOR COUNTY TICKETS; L.M. Swazey and Register O'Loughlin to Get Places on Kings Slate.
leadPara: The Executive Committee of the Fusion Committee of 107, after wrangling for several hours yesterday, decided to rearrange several of its county tickets. Just how many changes are to be made will be announced later. It was decided to leave the Queens ticket, with Robert W. Higbie as the Fusion choice for Borough President, as it was originally made up, as the anti-Higbie factions could not unite upon any other candidate.
abstract: Queens ticket unchanged; Kings ticket rearranged; Bronx protests taken up

headline: LA FOLLETTE OFFERS NEW WOOL SCHEDULE; Free Lists Some Classes of Raw Staple and Puts 15 Per Cent. Duty on Others.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Senator La Follette of Wisconsin, for the Progressive Republicans, introduced his substitute for the wool schedule of the Democratic Tariff bill in the Senate today. He proposes rates substantially lower than those in the amendment offered some time ago by Senator Smoot of Utah, the tariff expert of the regular Republicans, and they are believed to be the lowest wool rates ever proposed by a Republican.
abstract: introduces new wool schedule in Senate

headline: M'CALL WILL RUN; GAYNOR IN RACE TOO; Mayor Will Head Third Ticket In the Fight for the City This Fall.
abstract: McCall receives nomination

headline: MODERN LEGAL PROBLEM; Mr. Frederic R. Coudert Discusses the Dangers Surrounding the Conflict Between Precedent and Progress
leadPara: PRECEDENTS embody the fruits of experience. None would frankly propose to defy the accumulated wisdom of the centuries, but many would defy all the precedents in the law books, so fierce is their desire to benefit humanity forthwith, to-day rather than to-morrow, and this minute preferably. On the other hand, some are such sticklers for precedents and regularity of procedure that they would hang a man known to be innocent because he has been convicted.

headline: NEW HAVEN TRAIN MISHAP.; Wreck of an Express Train Is Narrowly Averted.
leadPara: NEWINGTON, Conn., Aug. 23. -- Derailed here by a railroad tie which it had picked up at Berlin and carried the four miles to this point, a big Pacific type of engine, drawing the Connecticut River Special, northbound, over the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, narrowly escaped plunging with its train down a ten-foot embankment.
abstract: Beveridge C. Dunlop designated by Republicans and Progressives, Frederick G. Grimme designated by Democrats

headline: NEWS OF SCHOLASTIC INSTITUTIONS.; Wild Flower Garden at Branford Hall School -- Improvements for Westchester Military Academy -- At Other Institutions.
leadPara: At the Branford Hall School for Girls at Bronxville there is an interesting wild flower garden, devoted and restricted to only such wild flowers as grow within fifty miles of New York.
abstract: Faculty, changes in

headline: TO SIFT CONGRESS RECORD OF SULZER; Resolution for an Inquiry Into His Relations with Contractors Goes to House This Week.
leadPara: A Congressional investigationu will be asked for early next week, probably on Monday, into the relations between the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, at the time when William Sulzer was a prominent member, and the firm headed by Hugh J. Reilly, the contractor, who had a contract to build waterworks at Clenfuegos.
abstract: activities of Sulzer in his behalf

headline: SENATOR'S CLERK, SHOT, NAMES CHUM; F.A. Reilly, Wounded Dangerously, Accuses National Progressive Employe.
abstract: Reilly, Francis A., shot; accuses D. H. Schultz

headline: OUR SCHOOL PROBLEMS HARDER THAN THOSE OF EUROPE; Because of the Varied Sources of Our Population the Difficulties of Our Educators Are Greatly Increased --Distinguished Foreign Experts Discuss Some Phases of Their Own Work in Schools and Ours.
leadPara: FOREIGNERS of distinguished achievement and high position have numerously passed through New York recently, bound for the Fourth International Congress on School Hygiene, to convene in Buffalo on the 25th and remain in session through the 30th of this month.

headline: FUSIONISTS SAVED THE CITY MILLIONS; Citizens' Committee Issues a Statement Showing Reforms in the Purchase of Supplies.
leadPara: The Citizens' Municipal Committee, which has put an anti-Tamany ticket in the field issued another statement yesterday intended to show the difference between Tammany and anti-Tammany city government. The work of the Fusion Board of Estimate in reorganizing the city's method of purchasing supplies, by which millions of dollars were saved and the obstacles said to have been put in the way of the reforms by the Tammany Legislature were set forth.
abstract: defeats T. B. Maloney at Democratic primaries

headline: COLONEL WON'T CELEBRATE; Roosevelt Will Stay Away from Progressive Birthday Party.
abstract: will not attend birthday celebration of the Progressive Party

headline: RENEW FIGHT FOR NON-PARTY JUDGES; Lawyers Will Strive to Get Leaders to Compromise on Court of Appeals Candidates.
leadPara: Democratic, Republican, and Progressive Party leaders in this State will take up this week the question of selecting bipartisan candidates for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and Associate Judge, Successors to Chief Judge Edgar M. Cullen and Associate Judge John Clinton Gray, who will retire because they have arrived at the age limit, will be elected in November.
abstract: fight for nonparty Judges renewed

headline: OTTINGER STARTS BOLT FROM MITCHEL; Republican Leader Calls Him a Mask for Hearst and Offers to Support Gaynor.
abstract: Murphy at work on slates

headline: STOKES FOR YOUNG MEN.; Ex-Governor Says They Must Run the Republican Party.
abstract: wants new deal in G. O. P. organization, would have young men run the party

headline: NO COMPROMISE, SAYS ROOSEVELT; He Tells Chicago Progressives the Republican Party "Must Adopt Our Principles."
leadPara: CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 27. -- The Progressive Party is to continue. The slogan of "No compromise with the Republican Party" was sounded by Theodore Roosevelt at a luncheon in the Chicago Progressive Club at noon to-day.
abstract: addresses Chicago Progressive Club; says Republicans can unite with them by adopting their principles

headline: TAMMANY TO FILL ITS TICKET TO-NIGHT; At Least for Candidates for Supreme Court, Goldfogle Being the Latest.
leadPara: Tammany leaders were at work all day yesterday on their county, borough, and judicial slates, which will be decided upon to-night at a meeting of the three designating committees at Terrace Garden. Charles F. Murphy and his lieutenants have been considering many names of candidates and slowly eliminating the undesirables.
abstract: designated by Tammany for Justice of Municipal Court

headline: TOPICS OF THE TIMES.
leadPara: Prof. G.T.W. PATRICK of the Iowa State University contributes to the current Popular Science a novel, interesting, and at least plausible explanation of the human demand for alcohol -- a demand which exists all over the world, and not only persists, but apparently increases, in spite of the equally widespread conviction that the intoxicants are all destructive poisons, admitted even by such few and faint friends as they have to be socially injurious.
abstract: his statement criticised, editorial

headline: NAME HAVENS FOR MAYOR.; Rochester Fusionists Unite on Man Who Beat Aldridge for Congress.
RALLY LEGISLATORS FOR GLYNN MESSAGE; Full Attendance Urged for Tonight, When Acting Governor Will Be Formally Recognized.
abstract: arrives from the West, will attend meeting of the Progressive State Committee at Rochester

headline: PRAISES WILSON'S MOTIVES.; But London Graphic Doubts if His Policy Is Practical.
HEARST MEN BOLT FUSION NOMINEES; Denounce McAneny and Prendergast for Broken Pledges and Name Substitutes.
leadPara: The plan to knife the Fusion ticket by repudiating at the Independence League City Convention last night the nominations of Prendergast and McAneny for Controller and President of the Board of Aldermen was carried out. The convention was marked by dissension and bitterness.
abstract: is named by Tammany and Independence League for District Attorney

headline: INCOME TAX IN SENATE.; Test Shows Republicans Are Inclined to Assist the Democrats.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- There were strong indications this afternoon that the Democrats of the Senate would be able to count as much on Republican votes in defeating amendments to the income tax section of the Tariff bill as in defeating attempts to modify the dutiable schedules.
abstract: Sen. Borah's amendment defeated; Republicans inclined to assist Democrats

headline: ROOSEVELT PLEA TO HELP MITCHEL; Hapgood Induces the Colonel to Argue for Straight Fusion Ticket.
leadPara: The political situation in the city, so far as Fusion is concerned, was complicated further last night when Col. Theodore Roosevelt issued a statement in which he advised all the Fusion candidates to remain on the Fusion ticket and not accept a nomination on any other. This, he said, was the only way to support Fusion and beat Tammany as the only anti-Tammany ticket in the field was the Fusion one.
abstract: refuses to say whether he will accept nomination on Gaynor ticket

headline: GAYNOR IN THE RACE WITH FULL TICKET; Has Entered the Mayoralty Contest "with Old-Time Vigor and Spirit."
leadPara: Mayor Gaynor, through his campaign managers, Fire Commissioner Joseph Johnson and R. Ross Appleton, announced formally last night that he would enter the Mayoralty race as an independent candidate. Campaign headquarters was opened at the Hotel Breslin, and Mr. Appleton said that the Mayor would make a vigorous campaign.
abstract: announces plans for Gaynor campaign

headline: MURDOCK IN MAINE FIGHT.; Appeals to Voters to Send a Progressive to Congress.
abstract: candidate for Progressive Congressman from Maine

headline: GLYNN RECOGNIZED BY LEGISLATURE; Despite Protests, Messages from Acting Governor Are Received by Both Houses.
leadPara: ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- Martin H. Glynn to-night received ormal recognition as Acting Governor from the Legislature when both branches received messages from him the first communications of ths nature since Gov. Sulzer was impeached. There were protests in both houses against receiving the messages.
abstract: Glynn recognized as Acting Governor when messages are received by both Houses

headline: GERMANS LEAVE FOR WEST.; Olympic Commission to Return for Metropolitan Championships.
leadPara: The Imperial German Olympic Commission consisting of Carl Diem, General Secretary of the German Olympic Committee for the Sixth Olympiad at Berlin, 1916; Lieut. Walter Reichenau, the representative of the German Secretary of War; Dr. Martin Berner, and Joseph Waitzer, Director of Athletics in Munich, left New York last night for Washington, D.C., where they will present their credentials to the German Ambassador.
abstract: rules for 24-hour race

headline: GIVE MITCHEL UP TO SAVE THE SHIP; Estimate Board Considered the Great Stake -- Its Members in Secret Conference.
leadPara: Fusion received another setback yesterday, when it was reported on very good authority that both George McAneny, the candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen, and William A. Prendergast, the nominee for Controller, would accept similar places on the Gaynor independent ticket if they were offered to them.
abstract: McAneny likely to accept nomination if offered to save Board of Estimate from Tammany

headline: THE WAY OUT.
leadPara: Mr. WHITMAN accepts the Tammany nomination for the District Attorneyship because he wants to be elected to the office. That is what he is running for. The Fusion Committee nominated him in order that he might be elected to the office. Without the Tammany nomination or indorsement he might have been defeated.
abstract: editorial

headline: INCOME TAX BOLT FOR HIGHER RATES; Radical Democrats in Senate Revolt Against Underwood Provisions, Joining Progressives.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Many important developments to-day marked the most stirring session the Senate has yet devoted to the consideration of the Tariff bill. The income tax section was the immediate issue, and a revolt of radical Democrats to-night threatens amendments to that provision of a far-reaching character.
abstract: objects to exemption of middle class from income tax

headline: NEW NOTES PASSED IN MEXICAN CRISIS; Full Text of Correspondence That Resulted in Lind's Return to Capital.
leadPara: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 28. -- The Mexican Government published to-day in The Diario the second note submitted to it by John Lind, President Wilson's emissary, and the reply made by Federico Gamboa, Minister of Foreign Relations. Mr. Lind's note follows:
abstract: manner in which he was selected as Pres. Wilson's representative in Mexico; he will remain in Vera Cruz; text of his second note to Gamboa

headline: A NEW DEFENSE OF SULZER.
leadPara: The Review of Reviews, to which we are accustomed to look for sound expositions of Progressive doctrine, has put forth a new and most interesting defense of Gov. SULZER against the impeachment charges. On legal and constitutional grounds it justifies his resolve to continue the exercise of the Executive functions while under impeachment.
abstract: editorial

headline: TO NOTIFY GAYNOR ON CITY HALL STEPS; Mayor in a Speech Will Accept the Nomination and Attack Tammany.
leadPara: Mayor Gaynor is to receive the nomination for Mayor on an independent ticket on the steps of the City Hall at noon next Wednesday. This was decided upon last night at a meeting of some 350 of his supporters at the headquarters of the Gaynor Campaign Committee at the Hotel Breslin.
abstract: will receive nomination on City Hall steps

headline: WHITNEY'S PENNANT FUTURITY FAVORITE; Famous Turf Classic Will Have Only Nine Starters in To-day's Running.
leadPara: SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Robert Davies, the Canadian sportsman, won his first purse of the Saratoga season this afternoon when his chestnut colt The Usher outfooted and outgamed Richard Carman's Surprising in a five-and-a-half-furlong handicap. The race had a particular significance, for it afforded a line on the quality of Southern Maid, the Davies candidate for the Futurity, to be run to-morrow.

headline: ROOSEVELT QUITS FUSION IN ANGER; Rebuffed at McAneny Conference, He Throws Hands Up in Disgust.
abstract: declines indorsement by Independence League; pressure being brought to bear upon him to retire; calls conference; receives letter from Rabbi Wise

headline: LAMAR WOULD BARE A LOBBY; Offers to Tell Senators of One Supported by Big Railroads.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- David Lamar, the Wall Street operator who recently confessed under oath before the Senate Lobby Committee that he had impersonated many public men and for whom an indictment for impersonation with fraudulent intent is waiting in New York, is trying to get the committee to listen again to him.
abstract: David Lamar offers to reveal lobby supported by railroads to repeal Sherman Anti-Trust act

headline: REPUBLICANS ORGANIZE.; Woods, Progressive, Heads Committee to Frame Campaign Plans.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The Republican Congressional Committee organized to-day and outlined its general plans for the coming campaigns. Representative Frank P. Woods of Iowa, who is regarded as a Republican Progressive, was elected Chairman. He announced that the committee's work from now on would not be in the line of direct aid to individual candidates, but in furnishing information to the voters of the country.
abstract: Congressional Committee organizes; F. P. Woods Chairman; plans for coming campaigns outlined

headline: PROGRESSIVES' FIRST BIRTHDAY. WHAT OF THE FUTURE?; There Will Come a Revulsion and a Return to Republican Party Says Hilles. Progressives Certain of Increasing Success.
leadPara: THE hope of the Republican Party is the intelligence of the American people. The American people are a competent people, and nothing so quickly disgusts them and alienates them from a political party as incompetence. Nothing more effectively illustrates incompetence than the Democratic Party.

headline: CLARK TO MAINE VOTERS.; Election to Show If Country Is with Democrats, He Tells Them.
abstract: addresses Maine voters in the interests of William R. Pattangall

headline: PROSPEROUS CHILE WHERE REVOLUTIONS ARE UNPOPULAR; People There Are Imbued with the True Spirit of Civic Life, Says Gen. Reyes, Former President of Colombia, Although They Excel as Fighters.
leadPara: DIVIDED, respectively, on land and on water by the immense and imposing barrier of the Andes and the Straits of Magellan, the Republics of Chile and Argentina until three years ago were, far all practical purposes, as far apart as if they had been situated at the two extremities of the continent.

headline: MOOSE BIRTHDAY JUBILEE.; Twenty Thousand Progressives Celebrate in Chicago.
abstract: first anniversary celebrated in Chicago

headline: MITCHEL MAKES NEW ATTACK ON M'CALL; Cites Records to Show That Commissioner Favored Subway Contract Revision.
leadPara: John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, made public a formal statement yesterday tending to support the charge he made a week ago in his letter to Chairman Taylor of the Independence League Designating Committee that Edward E. McCall, the Tammany Mayoralty candidate and Chairman of the Public Service Commission, had already shown a disposition to abrogate the terms of the subway contracts and "revise them in the interest of the traction companies."

headline: GERMANY AND ENGLAND.
leadPara: Lord HALDANE speaks with a certain personal authority on the relations between England and Germany. Certainly he does not speak "as one of the scribes" who in one country and the other have ignorantly and wantonly stirred up suspicion and anger. It is significant, therefore, that the eminent statesman and scholar finds himself able to say that Anglo-German relations are becoming "increasingly cordial."
abstract: his views on relations between Germany and England, editorial

headline: MAINE ELECTION CRUCIAL.; Among First Since Congress Convened -- Test for New Tariff.
leadPara: WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 31. -- The special Congressional election in the Third Maine District, to be held on Sept. 8, to elect a successor to the late Representative Forrest Goodwin of Skowhegan, is regarded by all parties as of special importance, as it will be among the first since the present session of Congress was convened, with its Democratic majority.

headline: PROGRESSIVES BOLT MITCHEL FOR GAYNOR; Bronx League Heads Movement That Is Expected to Spread Throughout the City.
leadPara: Plans to swing the Progressive voters throughout the city to the support of Mayor Gaynor and away from John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion Mayoralty candidate, were launched yesterday. While the movement lacks the sanction of the Progressive leaders, it is thoroughly organized in the Bronx at least, and will be extended this week to the other boroughs.
abstract: is asked by leaders of Independence League to run for mayoralty

headline: ANTI-WEALTH POLICY.
leadPara: Various propositions are before Congress to tax the property of individuals or corporations more and more heavily the greater it is. Some of them propose a maximum tax of 8 per cent. Mr. LA FOLLETTE would go as high as 10 per cent. Mr. HITCHCOCK of Nebraska, who has broken loose from the caucus, wishes to run the tax up to 20 per cent.

headline: SEE THREAT OF BOLT IN REPUBLICAN 'TEST'; Leader Lyons Asks Voters Frankly to Decide Between Mitchel and Gaynor.
leadPara: Republican voters in several Assembly districts will have an opportunity this week to express their views as to whether John Purroy Mitchel or Mayor Gaynor should be the Republican nominee for Mayor. A postal card canvass was agreed upon yesterday by several Republican district leaders who said that they did not want to take the responsibility of deciding the question themselves.

headline: THE WISCONSIN WIVES' STRIKE.
leadPara: There is a new peril for men in the wives' strike in Wisconsin. So far as it is possible to make it out at this distance, the reason for this uprising of wives is the refusal of the State Board of Arbitration to permit the representatives of woman suffrage to have a booth on the State Fair Grounds at the fair to be held in the second week of September.

headline: REPUBLICANS CONFER.; Will Not Offer a Full Substitute for Currency Measure.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The Republican members of the House Currency and Banking Committee were in conference all of this afternoon and had before them the latest draft of the Glass Currency bill as perfected by the Democratic caucus. They have held several quiet conferences in the last ten days, but the meeting this afternoon was preliminary to the committee session called for to-morrow morning by Chairman Glass.

headline: FUSION 'STANDS PAT'; STICKS TO MITCHEL; Only Voluntary Retirement Now Can Make Change at Head of Ticket.

This means that the committee will stand solidly behind John Purroy Mitchel, its candidate for Mayor, and not try to have him withdraw.
abstract: Fusion Committee meets and decides to make no change in ticket; friends argue case; Mr. Bennet objects to attitude on subway question

headline: WANT NEWLANDS BACK.; Nevada Senator's Vote Needed Badly to Help Pass Tariff Bill.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept 2. -- The long-continued and unexplained absence of Senator Newlands of Nevada is causing the Democratic leaders renewed uneasiness as to the fate of the tariff bill when it comes up for final passage next week. Mr. Newlands has been in the West for nearly a month, and has steadily refrained from answering telegrams inquiring as to the date of his return and his attitude toward the bill.
abstract: Democratic Senators anxious that he should return to Washington; his vote needed to help pass Tariff bill

headline: MR. TAFT ON THE COURTS.
leadPara: It is pleasant to note that of all the men eminent in the law and in public life who attended the important meeting of the American Bar Association in Montreal, ex-President TAFT, Professor of Constitutional Law at Yale University, received the most cordial and the greatest applause. He deserves it.

headline: BARS TRUST CONTROL UNDER TARIFF BILL; Senate Vote Defeats Amendment to That End -- Separate Legislation Later.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- An attempt to introduce legislation aimed at trusts into the Tariff bill failed in the Senate to-day, when the Democratic majority with unbroken front, supported their leaders in defeating an amendment designed to regulate combinations.

headline: TAFT ELECTED HEAD OF BAR ASSOCIATION; No Other Name Presented for President at Final Session of Montreal Meeting.
leadPara: MONTREAL, Sept. 3. -- Ex-President Taft was unanimously elected President of the American Bar Association at the closing general session this afternoon, held at the Royal Victoria College. No other name was presented, and the announcement of his election was greeted with prolonged cheers.

headline: FUSION LEADERS FEAR THE KNIFE; Many Republicans and Progressives Threaten Openly to Cut Mitchel Ticket.
leadPara: While Mayor Gaynor was receiving the independent nomination at the City Hall yesterday, several of the Fusion leaders were busy at their headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Building planning their campaign. Having decided to make no changes in the ticket they had put in the field, the Fusion committee from now on will try to head off Gaynor sentiment among the Republicans and Progressives.
abstract: Gaynor sentiment growing; Lyons gets 5 Gaynor replies to 1 Mitchel

headline: ATTACK GAYNOR, NOW FUSION PLAN; Mayor Seizes Anti-Tammany Issue, So They Turn to Rend Him.
leadPara: Mayor Gaynor's vigorous attacks upon Tammany Hall in the past two days culminating in the bitter assault he made yesterday before he sailed to England on a vacation voyage, have upset completely the plans of the Fusion leaders. They are face to face with a peculiar situation.

headline: HEAR 7 CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNORSHIP; Men Seeking Jersey Executive Office Meet on One Platform in Newark.
leadPara: Seven candidates for Governor of New Jersey -- Acting Gov. James F. Fielder, Everett Colby and Edmund B. Osborne, Progressive Republicans; Carlton B. Pierce, Charles M. Fowler, and ex-Judge Robert Carey, Republicans, and James W. Mason, Prohibitionist -- spoke from the same platform at a meeting held last night under the auspices of the Clinton Hill Improvement Association in the Cleveland School, Newark.
abstract: addresses meeting at Newark under the auspices of the Clinton Hill Improvement Association

headline: MITCHEL RETURNS; ALARM FOR FUSION; Gaynor Aggressiveness Brings the Candidate Home for Many Hurried Conferences.
leadPara: Alarmed at the new Fusion crisis, due to the aggressiveness of Mayor Gaynor in seizing its main reliance, the anti-Tammany issue, John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, hurried out of the Adirondack woods and returned to the city yesterday.
abstract: alarmed by Gaynor aggressiveness Mitchel holds hurried conferences; full Fusion Committee meeting proposed

headline: REPUBLICANS DELAY PASSAGE OF TARIFF; Their Demand for Further Debate Postpones Vote Till Tuesday or Wednesday.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The demand of Republicans for more time to talk put an end this afternoon to the hopes of Democratic leaders to pass the Tariff bill through the Senate before adjournment to-morrow.

Friends said at midnight that, unless he changed his mind before to-morrow, he would accept the Progressive nomination, which had been tentatively offered to him.
