headline: SULZER NOMINATED FOR THE ASSEMBLY; Progressives of the Sixth District Select Deposed Governor as Candidate.
abstract: is nominated for Assembly by Progressives of Sixth District; explains his acceptance; report that he will have aid of Kopp, Republican candidate; may be made Speaker

headline: SULZER ASSERTS MURPHY TEMPTED HIM WITH MONEY; " He Told Me I Could Have All I Wanted" at Delmonico Meeting About Christmas.
leadPara: William Sulzer's explanation in his own words of the underlying reasons behind his impeachment was published yesterday in The Evening Mail. It had been dictated, it appeared, just as soon as the verdict of the Court of Impeachment released the ex-Governor from his "pledge of silence," a pledge given to his counsel, so he said.
abstract: Sulzer tells of offers and threats leading up to impeachment

headline: TELLS WHY HE RUNS.; Wants to Work for Honest Government -- Wife Urged Acceptance.
leadPara: ALBANY, Oct. 20. -- William Sulzer received official notification of his nomi- nation for the Assembly by the Pro- gressives of the Sixth New York As- sembly District shortly after 9 o'clock to-night. He had known unofficialy that he was to be the nominee, and had, indeed, accepted the nomination hours in advance.

headline: OFF FOR CHICAGO IN ELECTRIC AUTO; Attempt Being Made to Break Distance Record -- M.A.C. Plans a Bulletin.
leadPara: In an attempt to establish a new long distance record for electric vehicles, Col. E.M.W. Bailey, driving a current-propelled roadster, left New York at noon on Sunday bound for Chicago. If he succeeds in reaching the Windy City this will be the longest tour ever made by an electric machine.
abstract: Dividend declared

headline: AS MACK RECALLS IT.; Sulzer and Murphy Did Not Talk Alone in Washington.
leadPara: BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Norman E. Mack was asked to-night as to the statement made by former Gov. Sulzer concerning the conference at the Shorehom Hotel in Washington, where State matters were discussed with Murphy. He said he recalled the incident, but did not remember that Murphy and Sulzer talked alone.
abstract: says he never talked with Murphy in reference to appointment

headline: MURPHY TO THE GRAND JURY; He and Mitchel May Testify on the Charge of Colonizing.
leadPara: The Grand Jury took up yesterday the charge made by John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, that Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, had made arrangements to bring a large number of repeaters into the city to vote at the election. It was said yesterday that the Grand Jury might call upon both Mr. Mitchel and Mr. Murphy to testify.
abstract: Louis Jacobson indorsed by Progressives

headline: TELLS WHY SULZER WAS MADE NOMINEE; It Was Highest Office in Our Power, Says Leader Steindler.
leadPara: Politicians, business men, and rabbis of the Sixth Assembly District agreed yesterday that they had urged the nomination of William Sulzer for the Assembly by the Progressives in order, as it was expressed by a business man, to give Sulzer "a fighting chance to keep alive."
abstract: men of Sixth District tell why Sulzer was made nominee; Lorence glad to retire in his favor

headline: OUSTED FOR ENDING TAMMANY'S GRAFT; War Begun on Him, Sulzer Avers, for Forcing State Architect Hoefer to Resign.
leadPara: William Sulzer continued yesterday his attack upon Tammany Hall, Charles F. Murphy, and Edward E. McCall through the columns of The Evening Mail. In a prepared statement given to James Creelman he told what he said was the inside story of his removal of State Architect Hoefer.
abstract: McCall talks to meeting of lawyers; Voters' Weekly shows list of refereeships he accepted

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: BAR ASSOCIATION OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK

headline: SULZER GREETED AS POPULAR HERO; Crowd of 5,000 Persons Storms Grand Central Terminal to Welcome Him Home.
leadPara: William Sulzer made a triumphal entry into this city last night. When he stepped off the train from Albany and walked into the Grand Central Terminal at 10:25 P.M. he was greeted by more than 5,000 persons, who shrieked approval of him, swung cowbells, blew horns, and gave college yells specially adapted to the occasion.
abstract: is greeted as hero by crowd on arrival in N. Y.; auto parade follows him, makes speech promising further revelations

headline: Editorial Article 1 -- No Title
abstract: editorial

headline: SULZER FRENZY HITS EAST SIDE; Cheering Thousands Block Deposed Governor's Car and Risk Lives for a Smile.
leadPara: At the beginning of his campaign for election to the Assembly from the Sixth District William Sulzer last night received convincing evidence of the fact that his impeachment and removal from the Governorship had not diminished his popularity on the lower east side. His reception was like the homecoming of a great war hero.
abstract: is cheered by thousands on east side, speaks in the street and is hailed as "next President,"

headline: TAFT PAYS TRIBUTE TO PRINCETON'S SAGE; Glowing Appreciation of Grover Cleveland Marks Speech at Dedication Exercises.
leadPara: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The Graduate College of Princeton University and the Cleveland Memorial Tower were dedicated to-day with impressive exercises. The American flag which flew above the White House during the second Presidential term of Grover Cleveland is fluttering to-night above the tower.
abstract: presents Cleveland Memorial Tower to Princeton University at dedication services of the Graduate College

headline: M'CALL IS SILENT ON HENNESSY'S CHARGES; " I'll Take Care of Them as a Man Ought to" All He Will Say in Direct Reply.
leadPara: Edward E. McCall had little to say yesterday about the attack made upon him the night before by John A. Hennessy in his speech in the Bronx. Mr. Hennessy propounded a number of questions to Mr. McCall, one of them being:
abstract: McCall does not explain charges

headline: HENNESSY TO CALL GLYNN TO HIS AID; Tells of Funds That Went to Tammany Through Cram and Proposes an Investigation.
leadPara: John A. Hennessy, the investigator appointed by Gov. Sulzer, in another public speech last night suggested that Gov. Glynn call an extraordinary session of the Albany County Grand Jury to delve into alleged campaign contributions made by Tammany supporters in 1911, and through J. Sergeant Cram in 1910.
abstract: tells of funds that went to Tammany through Cram, proposes Glynn instigate investigation, explains about $35,000 note, says McCall paid Plunkett, tells of nomination of Lynch

headline: CHURCH WILL JOIN HANDS IN MISSIONS; Episcopal Convention Authorizes Co-operation with Boards of Other Christian Communions.
leadPara: The House of Deputies of the Protestant Episcopal General Convention, in session in the new Synod Hall at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, late yesterday afternoon adopted a resolution authorizing the General Board of Missions to co-operate with other Christian Boards of Missions in this country and elsewhere.
abstract: gives reception to visiting Bishops and wives

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: FEDERAL COUNCIL OF THE CHURCHES OF CHRIST IN AMERICA

headline: MURPHY IN PANIC,' SULZER DECLARES; Stirs Great Crowds on East Side by His Bitter Denunciation of "the Chief."
leadPara: William Sulzer found last night that there was a wide difference between his popularity in Forty-second Street and his popularity in the Sixth Assembly District. In the Eltinge Theatre, on West Forty-second Street, the ex-Governor and Progressive candidate for the Assembly from the Sixth District, received a demonstration that came very largely from employes of the theatre and outsiders commandeered by the management.
abstract: McCall speaks in Staten Island; does not discuss Hennessy charges

headline: CURRENCY OUTLOOK SUDDENLY CHANGED; Vanderlip Submits Single-Bank Plan Which Has Senate Committee's Support.
abstract: Vanderlip, Frank A., proposes new measure to Senate Committee, his summary of plan

headline: A WISCONSIN IDEA.
leadPara: President VAN HISE of the University of Wisconsin has propounded a novel variation of the Wisconsin idea. The Wisconsin idea is that all good things are attainable by legislation -- if only legislation is made perfect in the first place. President VAN HISE'S variation is that until the laws are perfected they shall be equitably applied to all, whether rich or poor.
abstract: Wisconsin Idea, editorial on speech on Sherman anti-trust law by Dr. Van Hise

headline: Abram I. Elkus's Supporters.
abstract: letter by Harold Kellock in support of candidacy

headline: HENNESSY TO TELL STILWELL SECRETS; Used Dictophone in Convicted Senator's Cell and Will Reveal Results on Monday.
leadPara: John A. Hennessy, the special graft investigator appointed by ex-Gov. Sulzer, told a large audience at Prospect Hall, Brooklyn, last night that he would add to his revelations of graft in Tammany on Monday night, by relating parts of a five-hour conversation he had with ex-Senator Stilwell in his cell in Sing Sing.
abstract: Hennessy makes further disclosures

headline: NEW JERSEY TO HAVE A NEW GOVERNOR; Fielder Goes Out to Make Prospective Election Legal -- Taylor Succeeds Him.
leadPara: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Oct. 24. -- Acting Gov. James F. Fielder announced here to-day in the course of his campaign trip that on Monday next he would resign as President of the State Senate. Automatically then he will cease to be Acting Governor. Leon R. Taylor, Speaker of the Assembly, will become Acting Governor automatically.
abstract: Gov. Fielder will resign and let Speaker take his place as Governor to make prospective election legal

headline: CALL BIRD A BOSS.; Progressives of 25th Assembly District Come Out for McCall.
abstract: McCall will have support of Progressives of 25th Assembly

headline: VOTERS' GUIDE FOR THE NEW ASSEMBLY; Candidates and Their Qualifications as the Citizens' Union Finds Them.
abstract: Directory of candidates to Assembly from Greater New York

headline: FOUR AMENDMENTS BEFORE THE VOTERS; The First Would Change the Method and Scope of Condemnation Procedure.
abstract: amendment to be voted upon

headline: RYAN'S $10,000 WENT TO MURPHY, SULZER SAYS; Gift Was in Cash, He Declares, and He Sent It to the Boss by John H. Delaney.
leadPara: Speaking to multitudes, who received him with marks of fanatical enthusiasm, during his tour of the Sixth Assembly District, William Sulzer last night declared that he had sent to Charles F. Murphy the $10,000 which Allan Ryan had contributed to his campaign fund, and that Murphy had never accounted for it.
abstract: campaign gift went to Murphy according to Sulzer

headline: EX-ASSEMBLYMAN EXPOSES TAMMANY; E.R. Terry Met Intimidation and Every Other Shameful Device, He Writes.
leadPara: In an article entitled "How Murphy Works," printed in Harper's Weekly of yesterday, Edmund R. Terry, a member of the Assembly in 1908 and 1911 from the First Assembly District of Kings County, sets forth a scathing arraignment of the methods used by Tammany Hall to prevent the election of opposition candidate, which, he says, were carried so far that even the children were made to suffer because their parents were against the organization.
abstract: Article by E. R. Terry disclosing methods used by Tammany

headline: FUSIONISTS EXPECT MITCHEL LANDSLIDE; Hennessy Revelations Have Reversed Previous Sentiment for McCall, They Say.
leadPara: In the last week the political situation in this city has been reversed. A few days ago Tammany was overconfident and the Fusion forces were merely hopeful. The betting odds favored Edward E. McCall, the Tammany candidate for Mayor, 10 to 8. Now the campaign swings into its final week with the Fusionists sure of victory and the Tammany forces filled with despair.
abstract: landslide expected by Fusionists

headline: HOLLANDERS AFRAID OF THE MILITANTS; Former Miss Milholland Says the Men Don't Dare Oppose the Suffrage Movement.
leadPara: Mrs. Inez Milholland Boissevain spoke to the Women's Political Union at its Sunday afternoon tea yesterday about suffrage in her adopted country. Mrs. Boissevain is suffering from what she considers a "humiliating disability" in having lost her citizenship because of her marriage to a citizen of Holland, but she hopes to regain it in time to vote in this State if the women succeed in thier referendum in 1915.
abstract: addresses Woman's Political Union on woman suffrage in Holland

headline: SUFFRAGETTE SALES; Made Promiscuously, Hence Did Harm, Mrs. Scott Says.
leadPara: Chief Magistrate McAdoo in to-day's TIMES is quoted as saying that the articles, "The Dangers of Marriage," and "Plain Facts About Marriage," in The Suffragette, were "apparently based upon liberal quotations from the writings of the late Dr. Morrow of this city, and also from a book written by a New York woman, and for sale in the stores."
abstract: Mrs. F. M. Scott says harm came from promiscuous sale, letter

headline: DAILY COMMON SENSE CAMPAIGN TALKS; By a Man Who Believes in New York City and Judge McCall
leadPara: We talk to-day about Mr. Mitchel, one of the men who aspire to rule over the greatest and richest of cities. He seeks the chair graced by William J. Gaynor, that ancient prophet and mystic who came among us moderns out of some long gone age.

headline: HENNESSY ACCEPTS M'CALL CHALLENGE.; Puts His Main Charges Against the Tammany Candidate in an Open Letter.
leadPara: John A. Hennessy read in the newspapers yesterday morning that Edward E. McCall had dared him to put his charges in writing and furnish basis for redress through criminal action. It was a dare the former graft investigator was willing to answer. Within five minutes he called in a stenographer and got busy.
abstract: charges written by Hennessy

headline: CITY 41-2S AT 105 1-8; ALL MUNICIPALS UP; Rapid Advance Making a Stir -- Big Estates in Market Owing to Income Tax Exemption.
leadPara: There was a further rise in New York City bonds yesterday that was regarded by dealers as nothing short of sensational. The last issue of 4 1/2S closed at 105 1/8, as against 103 the day before. They were sold by the city on May 20 at a small fraction above par. and in June were quoted as low as 99 7/8.
abstract: Postponement of dates for settlement and special clearances announced by Stock Exchange

headline: M'CALL'S TURN NOW; HE ACCUSES MITCHEL; Asserts That He Used His Official Position to Aid Corporation of Which He Was Counsel.
abstract: plans for Fusion rally

headline: ELECT FIELDER, SAYS BRYAN; Jersey Can Thus Show Approval of Wilson's Works, He Asserts.
leadPara: SALEM, N.J., Oct. 30. -- William Jennings Bryan, Secretary of State, made his second appearance in New Jersey to-day in the interests of Senator Fielder and the State Democratic ticket. Mr. Bryan came across the Delaware River from Pennsylvania, landing at Penn's Grove, where he spoke to a large number of workers and farmer near the powder works there, and then he came here.
abstract: urges election of James A. Fielder

headline: SULZER IS TO START STATE-WIDE FIGHT; This Crusade Tame to the One He Will Wage on Grafters After Election, He Says.
leadPara: In a fiery speech, during which he criticised the Court of Appeals and savagely attacked Charles F. Murphy and Mr. Murphy's condidate for Mayor, Edward E. McCall, William Sulzer asserted last night in the Lenox Assembly that his fight here against Tammany was but child's play compared to the task he had set for himself.
abstract: Sulzer tells of efforts to prevent veto of Yard-Healy bill

headline: 12,000 AT GARDEN CHEER MITCHEL; Throng Applauds for Fifteen Minutes When Candidate Enters Fusion Meeting.
leadPara: Twelve thousand persons, all who could be admitted to Madison Square Garden under the fire regulations, cheered John Purroy Mitchel and the other Fusion candidates wildly last night and listened to men prominent in the affairs of the city, who spoke on their behalf at the biggest meeting of the campaign.
abstract: Mitchel speaks before enthusiastic meeting at Madison Square Garden; other speakers

headline: Progressives' Flag Torn Down.

BRONX CROWD GOES WILD OVER SULZER; Cheers Him for Twenty-one Minutes ;- Thousands Shout for Him in Harlem. QUESTIONS FOR MURPHY What "Financial Influence" Kept McCall from Court of Appeals, He Asks ;- In Fear of Violence.
leadPara: William Sulzer, the deposed Governor, ventured away from the lower east side to address meetings in Harlem and the Bronx last night, and received a royal welcome. The throngs which have followed his automobile about in the Sixth Assembly District, where he is running for Assemblyman, were missing, but in other ways his reception last night was one of the most spectacular of the campaign.
abstract: is received with enthusiasm in Harlem and the Bronx, urges support of Louis D. Gibbs and Michael Schaap, puts questions for Murphy

headline: ASSEMBLY LIKELY TO SEE UPHEAVAL; Up-State Forecasts and Estimates by Party Leaders Indicate Democratic Defeat. REPUBLICANS MAY HAVE 75 Democrats Credited with 49 Members, Including 12 Independents, and Moose 26. IMPEACHMENT A BIG FACTOR Marked Revolt Against Murphy Bossism Throughout the State ;- Some Bull Moose Losses.
leadPara: No campaign in the history of this State has been marked by such a bewildering number of interlocking candidacies. This, according to the leaders of all three parties, renders a reliable forecast in relation to the Assembly elections exceedingly difficult. In some localities the Progressive candidates have been indorsed by the Republicans.
abstract: in N. Y.

headline: Trend Against Schenectady Socialist.
Broome Progressives Aggressive.
Mixed Results in Onondaga.
Ulster Probably Republican
Revolt Against Murphy in Erie.
leadPara: BUFFALO, Nov. 1. -- With the direct primary fight still a most important factor, a number of Erie County Assemblymen are doomed to defeat at the polls next week because of the combination of anti-Murphy Democrats, Republicans, and Progressives. The organization Democrats cannot hope to elect more than two of the nine Assemblymen.

headline: STEPHEN PHILLIPS; Lyrics That Fulfill Promise of Fifteen Years Ago LYRICS AND DRAMAS. By Stephen Phillips. John Lane Co.

TAMMANY LEADERS HAND IN ESTIMATES; Murphy Takes Them to Study, but Is Still of the Opinion That He Will Win by 150,000. JOHNSON RAISES HIS FIGURE Now Says McCall Will Get 350,000 Vote ;- Just Like Ten Years Ago, Says ex-Mayor McClellan.
leadPara: Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, made the prediction yesterday that the Tammany ticket would win on Tuesday by 150,000 plurality. Every district leader in New York was at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam yesterday and turned in the estimates from their several districts of the result in sealed envelopes, following the Tammany custom of years.
abstract: Fusion leaders predict victory on city and county tickets

headline: Same Chautauqua Delegation.
No Change Likely in Monroe.

90,000 PLURALITY FUSION FORECAST; Campaign Manager's Figure Is Raised as High as 150,000 by Other Leaders. MURPHY STICKS TO 150,000 While Campaign Manager Johnson Now Says McCall Will Poll 350,000 Votes. THE BOROUGH FORECASTS Conflicting Claims of Two and Three Parties Outside Manhattan Set Forth on Election Eve.
leadPara: With the election only two days away and each side promising to keep it lively up to the very last moment, there are widely divergent views of the result from the different camps.
abstract: predicts victory for Mitchel in Bronx County

headline: CURRENT FICTION; Novels by Miss Willcocks, Mrs. Fraser and Others THE WILL TO LIVE. By M.P. Willcocks. The Mcmillan Company. $1.35 net.

SEEK TO DISCREDIT YOUNG M'LAUGHLIN; Father Denies Lending Money to McCall and Declares That His Son Is Irresponsible. SAY THE YOUTH WAS "USED" " Weak-Minded Boy," McCall Asserts; "Didn't Comprehend the Villainy That Was Forced on Him."
abstract: McLaughlin says son is irresponsible and denies lending money

headline: Republican Gains in Albany.
abstract: defeat expected, Sulzer impeachment an issue

headline: MEN AND AFFAIRS DISCUSSED BY COL. HARVEY; The Currency Bill, the Sacrifice of Sulzer, Humiliating the Vice President, the Progressing Colonel, the Tragedy of the Contentnea and Other Topics of Interest.
leadPara: THAT is a very interesting pen picture of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency which appears upon other pages of this November number of The North American Review -- interesting in itself and doubly interesting because it is drawn by the President of the greatest national bank in the country.

headline: SULZER THREATENED WITH ASSASSINATION; Warned That He'll Be Killed if He Goes into Sixth District on Election Day. THREAT TO INDICT HIM, TOO Stilwell's Counsel Is Busy with That, but Won't Tell Who's Behind Move ;- Sulzer Unafraid.
leadPara: William Sulzer has been threatened with assassination for his activities in the anti-Tammany campaign if he dares on Election Day to venture into the Sixth Assembly District, where he is a candidate for the Assembly.
abstract: ill

headline: WANTS TO BE EUGENIC BRIDE; New York City Girl Offers to Accept Colorado Health Offer.
abstract: Colorado Board of Health receives offers from N. Y. S. women, offering to be eugenic brides

headline: DR. LIPSKY FIGURES ON THE JEWISH VOTE; Shows by Analysis That This Vote Favored Straus Generally in Last Election. EAST SIDERS ARE UNITED Inclined to Support a Jew Against a Gentile on Even Grounds ;- Doubt in Sulzer's Case.
leadPara: The question whether or not there is among the Jews of this city a "Jewish vote" that can be depended upon for political purposes is ingeniously analyzed in a current issue of The American Hebrew by Dr. Abram Lipsky in connection with the sudden and interesting outburst of popularity of William Sulzer on the east side among people with whom as a class he seemed to feel he had earned gratitude.
abstract: analyzes Jewish vote in New York City

headline: M'CALL, SULZER SAYS SOUGHT HIS HELP; Interprets Feigl's Letter as Promising to Stop Impeachment in Return for Indorsement. GIVES FACSIMILE LETTER McLaughlin's Son Reiterates His Story of the Alleged Campaign Loan to McCall. YOUNG M'LAUGHLIN ANSWERS FAMILY
abstract: promised to stop impeachment, Sulzer says, if he indorsed nomination, letter given out

headline: NEW JERSEY IN DOUBT.; Election May Turn on Vote Polled by the Progressives.
BIRD ASSAILS REPUBLICANS.; Republican Column Not the only Fusion Column, Says Progressive.
leadPara: Francis W. Bird, County Chairman of the Progressives, issued yesterday a statement in which, on the eve of the anti-Tammany fight, he tried to revive the Republican-Progressive bickerings. He admitted that the election of the Fusion city ticket was a foregone conclusion and then went on:

headline: TERRAZAS A PRISONER.; Wealthiest Man in Mexico Said to be Held by the Federals.
leadPara: EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 3. -- Gen. Terrazas, reputed to be the wealthiest man in Mexico, is reported a prisoner of the Federals at Juarez. Military officials in Juarez deny knowledge of his presence, but the rumor is persistent that Terrazas and members of his family came to Juarez yesterday on the special train that brought Gen. Francisco Castro, and that Terrazas was detained.
abstract: report that P. A. Warner is his personal treasurer denied by Ogden Mills

headline: POLICE SHAKE-UP TO PROTECT POLLS; Waldo Shifts All Captains in Five Boroughs at Order of Mayor Kline. FUSIONISTS FORCE MOVE Mayor Makes Demand After a Conference with Mitchel and Manager Adamson. 8,000 WARRANTS ISSUED 700 Plain Clothes Men Under Orders to Arrest Guerillas and Gunmen on Sight. POLICE SHAKE-UP TO PROTECT POLLS
leadPara: Extraordinary precautions were taken yesterday to make sure that the police would do their utmost to-day to prevent illegal voting and the intimidation of voters by gangsters at the polls. Mayor Kline after a conference with John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion candidate for Mayor, and Robert Adamson, manager of the Fusion campaign, requested Police Commissioner Waldo to shift every Police Captain in the five boroughs of the city.
abstract: shifts all police captains to protect polls

headline: SULZER VISITS SIXTH IN SPITE OF THREATS; And Will Direct Campaign There To-day, He Says ;- Speaks to 50,000. WANTS TO BE SENATOR Plan to Make Him Speaker Already Under Way ;- State Tour to be Begun at Once.
leadPara: William Sulzer wound up his campaign for election to the Assembly by a tour of the Sixth District last night, during which he exhorted the voters to get out early and vote the straight Bull Moose ticket. He had studied the situation carefully, he said, and found this ticket the best of the lot.

headline: Auburn Turns Republican.

Sulzer Elected to Assembly Two to One In Sixth; HIS UP-STATE FOES BEATEN Democrats Who Voted to Impeach Him Are Defeated in Rural Districts. BAD DAY FOR DEMOCRATS Latest Returns Show 85 Republicans in Next Assembly Out of 150. PROGRESSIVE GAINS LARGE Few Bull Moose Candidates Not Indorsed by Other Parties Win. NEXT SPEAKER A REPUBLICAN Seventeen Bull Moosers May Assist the Majority in Electing Him.
leadPara: Latest returns, with less than half a dozen districts in doubt or not heard from, indicate that the next Assembly will be composed of 85 Republicans, 48 Democrats, and 17 Progressives. This will enable the Republicans to organize the Assembly and elect a Republican Speaker.
abstract: elect 17 members

headline: FIELDER ELECTED IN NEW JERSEY; Democrat Chosen Governor Over Stokes, Republican, by Plurality of 29,000. SENATE ALSO DEMOCRATIC Assembly Controlled by a Majority of 20 if Late Essex Returns Are Verified. LIGHT PROGRESSIVE VOTE Colby Polled Hardly One-Fourth of Roosevelt's Strength ;- Paterson Socialists Strong.
leadPara: Late returns from New Jersey indicate that James F. Fielder, Democratic candidate for Governor, has a plurality over Stokes, Republican, of about 29,000.
abstract: Fielder is elected over Stokes by plurality of 29,000; Pres. Wilson wires congratulations

headline: Johnstown Elects Progressive.
abstract: is elected Representative from Georgia

headline: LEE WINS IN MARYLAND.; President Wilson's Choice for Senator Victorious by 15,000.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Blair Lee, a Democrat, President Wilson's choice for United States Senator, was elected to-day to succeed William Jackson, Republican, by majority of at least 15,000. The Democratic leaders say it will reach 18,000.
abstract: early returns indicate election

headline: SULZER JUBILANT AT MURPHY'S DEFEAT; "Murphyism Is Dead," He Cries, "and I Struck the Abhorrent Thing the Deadly Blow." ELECTED TO THE ASSEMBLY Will Continue There His Warfare Upon the Grafters ;- Mrs. Sulzer Says He Is Vindicated.
leadPara: William Sulzer, deposed as Governor by Charles F. Murphy's order, and now Assemblyman-elect from the Sixth District, received the election returns last night in his temporary headquarters in the Broadway Central Hotel. The only persons with him at the time were Mrs. Sulzer and a few of the friends who stood by him throughout the impeachment proceedings and during his campaign against Tammany Hall.
abstract: is elected, says he has been vindicated

headline: DEMOCRATS SWEEP INDIANA.; Elect 32 Mayors in 46 Towns, Including Indianapolis.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4. -- Joseph E. Bell, Democrat, was to-day elected Mayor of Indianapolis by a plurality of 8,878, according to unofficial returns. His total vote was 23,770, while Dr. W.H. Johnson, Progressive, received 14,892; Charles A. Bookwalter, Republican, ex-Mayor, 14,569, and Dr. C.S. Woods, on the Citizens' ticket, received 1,532 in 98 out of 133 precincts.
abstract: is elected Mayor of Louisville

headline: ZEALOUS WATCHERS DELAYED THE VOTING; Most of Them Columbia Students, but Election Board Office Relieved Confusion. ASKED TOO MANY QUESTIONS Superintendent of Elections Voorhis Reports Orderly Day and Remarkably Heavy Early Vote.
leadPara: In spite of the bitterness which has characterized the campaign on both sides, yesterday's election, according to Supt. Voorhis of the State Board of Elections for the Municipal District of New York, was one of the quietest and most orderly in his experience. There was little or no trouble at the polling places, and the vote cast was unusually heavy.
abstract: statement by Supt. Voorhis

headline: Rochester Goes Republican.
THE NEXT LEGISLATURE.
TOPICS OF THE TIMES.
leadPara: While it cannot be said that any considerable percentage of our population has yet come, or is soon likely to come, to regard $250,000 as a trivial amount of money, still we have all heard so often in recent years of much greater sums given for public purposes, educational, aesthetic, or charitable, that but little attention would be paid to Columbia's last acquired quarter million had it not been bestowed anonymously.
abstract: editorial

headline: REPUBLICANS KEEP ALBANY.; Roll Up Big Pluralities Because of Democratic Split Over Sulzer.
abstract: Republicans carry city and county

headline: DEMOCRATS WIN IN BAY STATE; Walsh Elected Governor, Carrying with Him Entire State Ticket. PLURALITY MAY BE 60,000 Bird, Progressive, Runs Ahead of Gardner, Republican, for Second Place. FOSS IS SNOWED UNDER Indications That Governor Without a Party Has Failed to Carry Single District in State.
leadPara: BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 4. -- The Wilson Democracy swept the State to-day, Lieut. Gov. Walsh being elected Governor by a plurality which may reach 60,000, and carrying with him the entire State ticket. This is the largest plurality ever given a Democratic candidate in Massachusetts.
abstract: is defeated in Mass. Gubernatorial campaign

headline: KLINE ELECTED ALDERMAN.; Mayor Gets All but Forty Votes In His Home District.
abstract: is elected Alderman

headline: LOUISVILLE IS DEMOCRATIC.

ELECTION THRONGS IN TIMES SQUARE; Newsboys Pushing Pink Extra of McCall Victory When Times Tower Flashed 'Mitchel Wins.' DENSE MASSES IN STREETS Parading, Shouting, Singing, and Tooting Horns ;- No Trouble, but Police Have Their Hands Full.
leadPara: Times Square was filled with noise and uproar, and the merriest and, possibly, the biggest election crowds in its history from early evening until after midnight last night. Police Inspector O'Brien, with 250 uniformed policemen, kept the crowd in order.
abstract: defeat indicated by incomplete returns

headline: HURT BY IMPEACHMENT.; Democrats Desert Ticket at Auburn, Amsterdam, and Other Places.

Up-State New York Rises In Revolt Against Murphy Domination; HE LOSES APPEALS COURT The Voters in Other States Stand Steadfastly by the President and His Policies. MASSACHUSETTS BY 60,000 Wilson's Personal Candidate, Fielder, Wins in New Jersey by 29,000. ELECT MARYLAND SENATOR Blair Lee's Victory There Answers the Criticisms of the Administration's Course. BRYAN, TOO, IS VINDICATED His Attitude In Going Into the State Provoked Criticism ;- Mayoralty Elections Generally Democratic.
leadPara: The Democrats still hold the nation. The predictions of a reaction have been unfulfilled. Blair Lee has carried Maryland and David P. Walsh has carried Massachusetts, the latter by the sweeping majority of 60,000. James F. headline: ALL GLYNN BILLS TO PASS THIS WEEK; Leaders Plan to Enact Reforms in Record Time and to End Session by Saturday. TAMMANY MEMBERS DAZED Murphy Now Said to Favor Initiative, Referendum, and Recall ;- Glynn on Workmen's Compensation. ALL GLYNN BILLS TO PASS THIS WEEK
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- "By order of the Boss," the Legislature, as firmly controlled by Tammany as ever, will pass the entire budget of anti-boss legislation recommended by Gov. Glynn in his special message. Furthermore, if present plans are carried out, all the Glynn measures will be passed this week, and the Legislature will adjourn sine die not later than Saturday.

headline: DISPENSING WITH COURTS AND JURIES.
leadPara: Attorney General MCREYNOLDS has announced his intention to settle his cases against big business out of court, whenever he is able to do so. The President wishes to help honest business, and also to protect investors. For this reason the New Haven suit for dissolution of the New England monopoly will be the last one brought, provided objectionable conditions are reformed without litigation.
abstract: editorial

headline: 1,000 APPLY FOR JOBS, NONE AS POLICE HEAD; Bird, Progressive Leader, First to File Applications with Mayor-Elect Mitchel. KOENIG IS CLOSE BEHIND Candidates for All Places Except Police Commissioner ;- Mitchel Will Ignore Murphy.
leadPara: It was politicians' day at the office of Mayor-elect John Purroy Mitchel, 55 Liberty Street, twenty-third floor, yesterday. For hours Mr. Mitchel listened to the appeals of leaders of the various political organizations in the city who want to share in the division of city patronage.
abstract: submits list of candidates for appointments to Mayor-elect Mitchel

headline: Last Step in Move to Compensate Them Is Deplored.
leadPara: The activities at Washington and Albany in relation to Workmen's Compensation bills brought me to submit a brief statement of some of the principles involved and some of the dangers which seem to be inherent in the proposition; without, however, discussing the merits or demerits of any particular bill.

leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- The Senate tonight cleared the calendar for action tomorrow on the Workmen's Compensation bill, passing the entire programme proposed by Gov. Glynn for electoral reform, a series of financial deficiency bills, and some routine measures. The bills passed included:

leadPara: Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson was the guest last night at a dinner given at Sherry's in recognition of his public services as editor, poet, and citizen. Ex-President Taft paid a warm tribute to Dr. Johnson for his work in the fight for the preservation of the natural beauties of the Yosemite and the Hetch Hetchy valley.

headline: REPUBLICANS PUSH SPRING CONVENTION; Congressional Committee Adds Its Voice to Call for Party Council for Reorganization. CUT SOUTHERN DELEGATIONS Three Plans Are Outlined to Reduce the Representation of the Solid South.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A long step was taken toward the reorganization of the Republican Party in time for the Congressional campaign next year when the Republican Congressional Committee to-day unanimously adopted a resolution favoring an early call for a special National Convention to consider the readjustment of Southern representation, recognition of primary laws, and other similar matters.
abstract: Congressional Committee adopts resolution favoring early call for Spring convention; three plans outlined to reduce representation of the solid South

headline: PROMISE NEW YORK AN ERA OF PROGRESS; New Officials Pledge Themselves to Work for City's Advance at Young Republican Feast. TO DISREGARD PARTY RULE Mitchel and McAneny Tell Guests Fitness Will Be the Only Test for Those Appointed to Office.
leadPara: Mayor-elect John Purroy Mitchel told the members of the Young Republican Club of this city at their third annual dinner at the Hotel Astor last night that in the selection of his Cabinet his first consideration would be the fitness of the man rather than his party service or the party emblem under which he voted.

headline: ALL GLYNN BILLS PASS IN A RUSH; The Legislature Adopts Every Measure Championed by the Executive and Adjourns. WILL BE SIGNED TO-DAY Unanimous Vote on Some of the Measures ;- $160,000 to Pay for Sulzer Impeachment. ALL GLYNN BILLS PASS IN A RUSH
leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- After enacting the entire programme of legislation recommended by Gov. Glynn, the extraordinary session of the Legislature adjourned sine die at 8 o'clock to-night. It has been the most eventful session of the lawmaking body in this State, for it staged the first impeachment of a Governor in New York.

headline: TWO POLICEMEN SHOT.; One of Three Men They Were Searching in Elizabeth Wounded.
leadPara: Michael Kennedy and Herman Fretz, patrolmen of the Elizabeth, N.J., force, who were on duty in plain clothes, and a stranger who had posed as a salesman were shot just before midnight last night and are in the General Hospital in Elizabeth.
abstract: Estabrooke, (Dr.) W. Ludlow, residence damaged

headline: TAFT IS IRONICAL ON PROGRESSIVISM; Ex-President's Witty Sallies Entertain Pennsylvania Society Dinner. H.P. DAVISON'S ADDRESS Banker Tells of New Responsibilities ;- Sutherland Denounces the Recall of Judges.

SAYS GERMANY LIKES MONARCHICAL RULE; Von Posadowsky Affirms Bulk of the Population Are Against Parliamentary Government. WON'T RISK INSTABILITY English Standards Not Applicable to the Fatherland, According to the Former Vice Chancellor.
leadPara: BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- American students of German political conditions may be surprised to learn that enlightened progressive German public men do not look upon recent events as having materially promoted the cause of parliamentary Government. They go further and say that such institutions are not desired by the vast bulk of the Fatherland's people.

headline: WHITMAN PRISONER SET FREE IN QUEENS; Mrs. Garcia, Arrested Here in Disorderly Resort Case, Released from Jail There. PROSECUTOR NOT NOTIFIED Contrary to Precedent ;- Queens Attorney Decided She Was Victim of Police Raider.
leadPara: A clash in authority between the District Attorney's office of New York County and the District Attorney's office in Queens County seems imminent as the result of the discharge by Judge Burt J. Humphrey in the Queens County Court last Friday of a woman convicted of violation of the tenement house law in this county.

headline: SHORT BALLOT NEEDED TO SIMPLIFY AMERICAN POLITICS; President of the City Club, Mr. Charles H. Strong, Tells the Necessity of a Reform Which Will Enable Voters to Know for Whom They Use Their Franchise.
leadPara: AN earnest fight for the "short ballot" has begun in New York State, and among the advocates of the simpler system none is stronger than Charles H. Strong, President of the City Club. He discussed the matter at length recently.

headline: ROOT SEES PERIL IN MONEY BILL; Measure Has Basic Defects of Bryan Doctrines, He Tells the Senate. PICTURES VAST INFLATION Says Prices Will Rise, Gold Vanish, Stocks Fall, Those Held Abroad Forced Home. PAWNING NATION'S CREDIT Gallinger Booms Root for Presidency ;- Vote on Bill Fixed for Next Thursday. ROOT SEES PERIL IN MONEY BILL
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Senator Root rarely makes a formal speech in the Senate, but to-day he assailed the Owen-Glass bill in one of the most eloquent addresses that chamber has heard in many years. The Democratic currency measure, he said, would fasten on a surprised country the fundamental defects of the Bryan doctrines, which the country had three times overwhelmingly repudiated.
abstract: formal speech in Senate assailing Glass Currency bill, points out basic defects, predicts disastrous results, nominated by Sen. Gallinger for next President

headline: A 1913 FAUST; Mr. Ficke's Masterful Version of the Old Theme MR. FAUST. By Arthur Davison Ficke. Modern Drama Series. New York: Mitchell Kennerley.
leadPara: THE first American product to be included in the Modern Drama series, edited by Edwin Bjorkman, with the purpose of furnishing a cross-section of to-day's drama here and abroad, is the "Mr. Faust" of Arthur Davison Ficke. There are some theatre-goers who would claim that "Mr. Faust's" place in such a drama series is best justified by the fact that it is no drama at all.

headline: PLAN TO FIT OUT BIG AQUITANIA SOON; Cunard Line's New Giantess Is About Ready to Leave the Clyde. EFFORTS TO INSURE SAFETY Double Skin in Vulnerable Parts ;- British Rules May Be Revised Governing Safety Appliances.
leadPara: According to reports received from Liverpool by the local agents of the Cunard Line, the new Aquitania is approaching complettion and it is expected will leave the shipyard at Clydebank early in the year and proceed to the Mersey, near Liverpool, to be fitted out for service.
abstract: Aquitania nearly completed; equipment

headline: ROOT AS PRESIDENT WOULD PLEASE TAFT; Ex-President Says Senator's Nomination by Republicans Would Delight Him. A FARSEEING STATESMAN Taft Compares Root to Hamilton and Puts Him at the Head of Those Who Serve the People Truly.
leadPara: " The nomination of Senator Root for President by the Republican Party would be gratifying to me -- highly gratifying. I would be delighted to see him in the White House I regard Mr. Root as a statesman in the same class with Alexander Hamilton. He is more than a statesman, too. He is a profound lawyer."
abstract: his nomination for President would delight ex-Pres. Taft, his ability praised

headline: SERIOUS PUBLIC DISCOURSE.
leadPara: There were notable after-dinner speeches made in this city Saturday evening. Ex-President TAFT and Mr. H.P. DAVISON at the dinner of the Pennsylvania Society, Mr. PROUTY of the Interstate Commerce Commission and President ELLIOTT of the New Haven Railroad Company at the Lotos Club, spoke in no light vein, as the orators of the dinner occasion are wont to do, but held discourse upon things of serious concern to the people of the country.
abstract: editorial

headline: WOMAN HEADS GARY POLICE.; Mrs. Ray Will Also Have Direction of the Fire Department.
leadPara: CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- A woman is to be put in control of the Police and Fire Departments of Gary, Ind., the seat of the big plant of the United States Steel Corporation. Mayor Knotts has announced that to-morrow he will appoint Mrs. Kate Woods Ray, a suffrage leader, to the Presidency of the Safety Board.
abstract: meets Thomas A. Edison, who thinks he can give her actual sound perceptions

headline: CURRENCY VOTE TEST FAVORS OWEN BILL; Senate Tables the Hitchcock Amendments, Including Federal Control of Banks. OWEN RETORTS ON ROOT Reed Also Condemns Senator's Attack ;- Weeks Defends Bankers ;- Defection of Lane.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Senate, in what was regarded as a test of strength on the Currency bill, laid on the table this afternoon the most important of the Hitchcock amendments by a vote of 40 to 35. Senator Poindexter, the only Roosevelt Progressive in the upper House, voted with the Democrats to shelve the Hitchcock proposal, while Senator Hitchcock was the only Democrat to vote against the motion.
abstract: Hitchcock amendments tabled by Senate in test of strength, Sen. Reed replies to Sen. Root, defends Owen bill, speeches by Senators Hitchcock, Stone and Weeks; Sen. Williams attacks Sen. Root

headline: REPUBLICANS VETO PARTY CONVENTION; National Committee Favors Referring Reorganization Problems to State Conventions. ACTION AT HILLES DINNER Expected That Conclusions Reached Will Be Ratified To-day ;- Strong Sentiment for Party Reforms. REPUBLICANS VETO PARTY CONVENTION
abstract: favored calling special convention

headline: REPUBLICANS VOTE DELEGATE REFORMS; National Committee Reduces South's Representation ;- No Special Convention Needed. APPROVES STATE PRIMARIES Detailed Plans to be Adopted Today and Then Referred to State Conventions for Approval. REPUBLICANS VOTE DELEGATE REFORMS
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Republican National Committee, in formal session at the New Willard Hotel to-day, decided to proceed direct, without the holding of a special national convention, to the reorganization of the national machinery of the party.

headline: SING XMAS GLEES AS BIG LINER SAILS; Mauretania Unable to Accommodate All Those Who Wish to Depart in Her. HOLIDAY MAIL IS HEAVY More Than $200 Worth of Postage Stamps Sold on the Pier ;- Notables Among the Passengers.
leadPara: Two thousand persons stood on the Cunard Line pier last night to see the Mauretania start at 6 o'clock on her third Christmas trip to Liverpool. The ship carried 1,870 passengers and 3,960 sacks of mail. Until ten minutes of the sailing hour messenger boys went to the big wating room at the head of the pier with late letters.

leadPara: ALBANY, Dec. 17.--It cannot be said with any degree of truth that the political bosses and their henchmen in this State are plunged in gloom over the enactment of the Glynn Direct Nominations bill. That measure received the approval of Gov. Glynn and went into effect to-day.

headline: G.O.P. TOO SICK YET FOR PEACE MEETING; Couldn't Stand Strain of Extra Convention While Convalescing, It Was Agreed. BARNES IS DISAPPOINTED Was Willing to Pave a Way for the Return of the Progressives -Marsh Is Satisfied.
leadPara: It is the general opinion among Republican leaders in this city that it should be left to the Republican State Committee to be elected at the primaries next Fall to take action on the plan adopted by the Republican National Committee at its meeting in Washington on Wednesday for the reduction of the representation from Southern States in future national conventions of that party.

headline: U.S. TROOPS KILL MEXICAN.; Huerta Regular Slain in Texas When He Fires on Sentries.
leadPara: PRESIDIO, Texas, Dec. 18. -- An exchange of shots between Mexican and American soldiers on the American line two miles west of Presidio resulted in the death of Luis Orozco to-day, a Federal regular from the army of Gen. Mercado.

headline: ELEVEN ON OHIO STRICKEN.; Four Other Sailors Probably Have Smallpox, Too ;- Eight Suspected.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The extent of the spread of smallpox among the crew of the battleship Ohio during her voyage from the Mediterranean to Guantanamo will not be wholly known for several days. Every precaution is being taken to detect the occurrence of new cases, and an extra detail of medical officers and nurses are on duty in the isolation hospital.
abstract: eight more suspected cases of smallpox on the Ohio

headline: GOVERNMENT TELEGRAPHS AND TELEPHONES.
leadPara: The Postmaster General's recommendation of Government telegraphs and telephones is so cordial that there can be no doubt of his personal attitude upon the question. As he is a Cabinet officer this might seem to bring the topic within the range of practical politics, were it not that the step from Cabinet officer to President is much longer than from Representative LEWIS to the Postmaster General.
abstract: editorial on his recommendation of Federal ownership of telegraph and telephone

headline: CURRENCY BILL PASSES SENATE; Owen Measure Adopted, 54 to 34, Six Republicans and One Progressive Supporting It. TRIUMPH FOR PRESIDENT Hitchcock's Substitute Measure, Offered as a Test of Strength, Beaten on Earlier Vote. CONFERENCE MEETS TO-DAY La Follette's Radical Amendment Barring Congressmen from Serving on Bank Boards Accepted. CURRENCY BILL PASSES SENATE
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The second great item on President Wilson's heavy legislation programme entered upon its final stage of enactment to-night when the Senate passed the Owen-Glass Currency bill by the overwhelming vote of 54 to 34. Though the measure carried a radical amendment, sponsored by Senator La Follette of Wisconsin, every Democrat present voted for it, and six Republicans -- both regular and progressive -- and one Progressive Party Senator joined them.
abstract: Administration measure passed by Senate

headline: BARNES WANTS FULL ASSEMBLY CAUCUS; Will Urge All Republicans to Attend, but Won't Push Hinman for Speaker. DESIRES THE BEST MAN Chairman Says He's Progressive and Will Serve Out His Present Term.
leadPara: State Chairman William Barnes, while he bitterly resents the activities of the group of local Republicans headed by Henry L. Stimson, Ogden L. Mills, and County Chairman Samuel S. Koenig to prevent the election of Assemblyman Harold J. Hinman of Albany to the Speakership of the Assembly, announced yesterday that under no circumstances would he take a hand in the contest.
abstract: announces that he will not participate in Speakership contest and urges full Assembly caucus

headline: "HENCE, LOATHED MELANCHOLY."
leadPara: The man of affairs who does not see in the chronicle of events put before him by the newspapers Saturday morning causes for profound satisfaction, for cheer, and for confidence, ought without delay to ask his family doctor to examine the slate of his digestion or some alienist to inquire into the state of his mind.

headline: CONFEREES HAVE CURRENCY BILL; House Refuses to Accept the Senate's Substitute for Glass Bill. SOME DELAY IS LIKELY Twenty Material Points of Difference Found ;- House Accepts Only Two Amendments. CONFEREES HAVE CURRENCY BILL
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The Currency bill was sent to a joint conference of the House and Senate for the adjustment of differences. With all Republican members excluded, the conference got down to work this evening and remained in session four hours. About twenty points of difference on essentials were discovered between the House and Senate drafts for the measure, while a partial reading of the bill suggested many changes in language.
abstract: extent of property holdings in London

headline: "HIGHER RATES OR GOVERNMENT OWNERSHIP";;-W.C. BROWN; Retiring President of the New York Central Thinks End of Private Control of Railroads Likely if Interstate Commerce Commission Does Not Decide Pending Rate Case in Their Favor.
leadPara: LIKE a majority of our business men, I am an optimist, and have unbounded faith in the future of this country and its institutions, especially in its form of government; but I firmly believe we are approaching a crisis when the influence of every thoughtful, conservative, patriotic citizen must be exerted to the utmost to stem the tide of socialism which has gained such ominous strength during the past decade.

headline: NO COMPROMISE POSSIBLE WITH REPUBLICAN BOSSES; G.W. Perkins Describes the Attitude of Their Committee as Brazen and Monstrous ;- No Hope of "Decent People" Affiliating with Them Again.
leadPara: The great big fact that stands out prominently in connection with the meeting of the Republican National Committee in Washington last week is that it formally and deliberately confessed its sins; and if there was anywhere in the United States a lingering doubt as to who broke up the Republican Party that action of these gentlemen in Washington last week must dispel any such doubt.
abstract: signed statement attacking Republican Party

MANHATTAN CLUB'S CAMPAIGN STARTED; Propaganda for Better Motoring Conditions for Public Brings in Members.
THE REAL PHILIPPINES QUESTION
leadPara: For us to leave the islands and to guarantee to the nations of the world, in exchange for the treaties of neutrality with respect to the islands, that law and order will be preserved and that there will be no civil commotion in which law and order cannot be maintained, would be an evidence of lack of sanity that I cannot think the American people would ever display.
abstract: editorial on his discussion of Philippine problem

headline: MITCHEL WILL PICK HIS MEN THIS WEEK; Mayor-Elect Will Try to Make His Final Selections by Elimination. TWO JOBS BOTHER HIM Puzzled Over Police Commissioner and Corporation Counsel ;- New County Officers Make Slates.
leadPara: Mayor-elect John Purroy Mitchel will begin this week to make his final selection of Commissioners who are to serve under him in the next four years. He has devoted three weeks of hard study to the problem Mr. Mitchel expects to have his slate, so far as the heads of departments are concerned, completed by the end of the week, but he will make no announcement of his selections until the middle of next week.
abstract: possible appointees

headline: 5,000 BOYS HOLD ELECTION.; Youngsters Vote for Mayor in Primaries In Seward Park.
leadPara: Seward Park, at East Broadway and Hester Street, was turned into an open-air political arena yesterday afternoon when 5,000 schoolboys from the east side, members of the Juvenile Citizens' Democracy, assembled there to hold a primary municipal election. The East Side Protective Association, made up of business men on the east side, who aim to make useful citizens of the boys, had charge of the affair.
abstract: Holds primary election

headline: THE REPUBLICAN OUTLOOK.
leadPara: It is not surprising that Mr. PERKINS should promptly reject the advances of the Republican National Committee. They really were not addressed to him, or to the far-away hunter whom for the time being he represents. On the contrary, they were meant to open the way for the return of the followers of Mr. ROOSEVELT whom Mr. PERKINS very naturally and earnestly wishes to retain.
abstract: editorial

headline: CUP DEFENDER'S KEEL.; Thirteen Tons of Lead to be Added to Vanderbilt Syndicate Boat.
leadPara: BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 22. -- A radical change in the original plans of the cup sloop designed by Nat Herreshoff for the Vanderbilt syndicate has been made whereby the craft will have added to the upper surface of the keel nearly thirteen tons more lead with provision to have no inside lead ballast.

headline: MONEY BILL GOES TO WILSON TO-DAY; House Accepts the Conference Report and Senate Will Vote This Afternoon. 35 REPUBLICANS FOR IT Two Democrats Against It in House, Where Final Vote Was 298 to 60. SENATE CHANGES UNLIKELY Agreement That Guarantee of Bank Deposits Will Be Made Subject of Separate Legislation.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- By the overwhelming vote of 298 to 60 the House of Representatives shortly before 11 o'clock to-night adopted the conference agreement on the Currency bill. The Senate remained in session until the conference report was received from the House and then adjourned until to-morrow morning under an arrangement to vote on the bill as agreed to by the conferees not later than 2:30 o'clock to-morrow afternoon.
abstract: explains changes made in currency measure passed by H. of R. at conference with Senate members, at meeting for final vote on bill

headline: EMPLOYES HONOR McANENY.; More Than 1,000 Hold a Dinner for Borough President.
leadPara: Employes of the city departments which come under the jurisdiction of the Borough President gave a dinner in honor of Borough President McAneny at Terrace Garden last night. A handsome bronze figure representing "Duty" was presented to Mr. McAneny by the employes of the Department of Public Works.
abstract: is given dinner by employes

headline: WON'T BACK SWEET; TOO NEAR BARNES; Anti-Organization Leaders Decide to Drop Him as Candidate for the Speakership. SURE HINMAN CAN'T WIN Clinton T. Horton and John Lee Sullivan Now Favored ;- Barnes Keeps Away from Fight.
leadPara: Assemblyman Thaddeus C. Sweet of Oswego has been dropped as the anti-Barnes candidate for Speaker. This was learned after a conference held at man up-town hotel last night by Ogden L. Mills, Treasurer of the New York County Republican Committee; Congressmen Charles M. Hamilton of Chautauqua, James S. Parker of Washington, and ex-Senator Harvey D. Hinman. The conferees constitute the "Big I Four" of the anti-Barnes movement in the RePublican State organization.

headline: SAY SCHMIDT IS INSANE.; More Alienists Testify at Trial ;- A Woman Faints.

White, for ten years connected with the United States Hospital for the Insane at Washington, was called yesterday as an alienist for the defense. headline: WHITE SLAVE FILMS CAUSE FRESH RAID; Pictures Which Caused Park Theatre Trouble Cut Off by Police at the Bijou. WOMEN MADE COMPLAINT Anti-Suffrage Leaders Seek Warrants from Magistrate Murphy ;- He Denounces Play.
leadPara: Deputy Police Commissioner Newburger and Sergt. Quinn, with six plain clothes policemen, raided the Bijou Theatre on Broadway, between Thirtieth and Thirty-first Streets, at 10 o'clock last night, and arrested the manager of the theatre and three other employes of the place, where a moving picture, "The Inside of the White Slave Traffic," was being shown.
abstract: Bijou Theatre raided; Solomon Hechter brings suit for libel because restaurant is shown

headline: Affixes His Signature at 6:02 P.M., Using Four Gold Pens.; LAUDS GLASS AND OWEN President Writes to Leaders Congratulating Them on Their Achievement. SENATE ADOPTS MEASURE By Vote of 43 to 25, Majority Including Three Republicans and One Progressive. BRISTOW ACCUSES OWEN Charges That Bill Will Benefit Leader as Banker, Which Owen Denies. WILSON SIGNS CURRENCY BILL
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23.--President Wilson signed the Currency bill at 6:02 o'clock this evening, following the passage of the conference report by the Senate in the afternoon by a vote of 43 to 25, and the House's approval of that report last night.
abstract: signs Currency bill with four gold pens, presents pens to Repr. Glass, Sen. Owen, and Sec. McAdoo, letters of congratulation to Repr. Glass and Sen. Owen, speech upon new legislation and what it will accomplish

headline: FAMINE THREATENS NOW IN BULGARIA; Thousands of Families Starving and Appeal Is Made to America for Aid. WOMEN AND CHILDREN PLEAD Country Needs Them, Miss Abbott Says, but They Will Die of Hunger This Winter Unless Assisted.
leadPara: Thousands of women and children in Bulgaria are facing starvation this Winter, according to Miss Inez L. Abbott, missionary of the Woman's Board of the Interior of the Congregational Church and Principal of the American Girls' Boarding School in Samokov, Bulgaria. Miss Abbott has come to this country to raise funds for the relief of 7,000 destitute families in the Samokov district.
abstract: Plea for aid from America for starving families made by Miss I. L. Abbott

headline: $100,000 RADIUM TEST TO SAVE BREMNER'S LIFE; Eleven Tubes Buried in Shoulder of New Jersey Congressman Stricken with Cancer. GREATEST TRIAL EVER MADE Dr. Kelly of Baltimore Applied the Remedy for Twelve Hours on Christmas Day. REPEATS OPERATION TO-DAY Watches for Reduction of Cancerous Growth and Is Hopeful of a Cure ;- Congressman Long a Sufferer.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Robert G. Bremner, Democratic member of Congress from the Seventh District of New Jersey, spent his Christmas in a Baltimore hospital with $100,000 worth of radium temporarily imbedded in his left shoulder in the hope that it would halt the growth of a malignant cancer there and perhaps destroy it.
abstract: radium applied by Dr. H. A. Kelly in effort to cure cancer

headline: HARE GETS MULLAN OFF MITCHEL SLATE; Mayor-Elect Puzzled Over a Corporation Counsel ;- Big Plans for Bruere. HARE GETS MULLAN OFF MITCHEL SLATE

It became known yesterday that he has about decided to abandon his first choice for Corporation Counsel, who was George V. Mullan, his former law partner, and that he is looking about for some one else for the office.
abstract: will not be appointed Corporation Counsel by Mitchel

headline: TWO SCHOOLS OF FOOTBALL.; Forward Pass Has Its Advantages, but Is a Dangerous Play.
leadPara: Football for 1914 promises to be the resultant of the forces of two contending schools, each denoting progress, but in a different way. An idea of the situation may be gathered from a brief review of the conditions that have led up to it.

headline: THE PRESIDENTS VISION, IS IT TRUE OR ILLUSIVE?; Col. George Harvey Comments Upon Mr. Wilson's Statement, "There Is but One Cloud Upon Our Horizon."
leadPara: SO begins the year of Our Lord 1914, in the view of the head of the nation. Is it a true vision or is it an illusion? Is its genesis to be found in the buoyancy of hope or in deduction from experience? A year hence we shall know.

headline: AGAINST REPUBLICAN UNION.; Woodruff, Progressive, Opposes United Convention in Michigan.
abstract: letter opposing union of Progressives and Republicans

headline: ANACONDAS FEAR COLONEL; But if One Gets Him Progressive Party Would Die, Speaker Says.
abstract: discusses Roosevelt and the tariff

headline: MARKS MAKES FEW CHANGES IN OFFICE; Borough President-Elect Retains Principal Incumbents of McAneny's Administration. RALPH FOLKS GETS A PLACE Is Selected as New Borough Secretary ;- Real Merit, Marks Says, Only Will Bring Men to Front.
leadPara: Marcus M. Marks, the Borough President-elect of Manhattan, made public the more important of his appointments yesterday. Almost without exception the executives now in charge of the borough's business have been retained in office. The newcomers into the President's official family are those who will be associated with him personally to a certain extent.
abstract: is dying; her career

headline: PLANS FOR A 'DRY' WAR HERE; W.H. Anderson Tells The Times What Anti-Saloon League Will Do.
leadPara: BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. -- William H. Anderson, who has resigned as Superintendent of the Maryland Anti-Saloon League to accept the position Jan.1 of Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League of New York, makes this statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES on his proposed plan of work in New York:
abstract: William H. Anderson to become superintendent, tells plans for a "dry" war

headline: WALDO RESIGNS; WILL GO WEDNESDAY; Police Department Headless When Mayor Mitchel's Administration Begins. PROTEST FROM MAYOR KLINE Commissioner Rescinds Order Transferring Heads of Bureaus and His Personal Staff. WALDO RESIGNS; WILL GO WEDNESDAY
leadPara: Police Commissioner Rhinelander Waldo yesterday sent his resignation to Mayor Kline, to take effect at any time, but in any event not later than midnight to-morrow. The resignation followed the Commissioner's compliance with request of Mayor Kline to rescind the order he made Saturday transferring heads of bureaus and members of his personal staff from Headquarters to precinct duty.
abstract: Police Commissionership undecided, W. C. Forbes declines

headline: TAGGART TIGHTENS GRIP.; Completely Controls Indiana Machine ;- Wilson-Bryan Men Revolt.
leadPara: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 29. -- "Tom" Taggart to-day tightened his grip on the Indiana Democratic organization and won the most spectacular victory of his career. Every one of the thirty district committeemen chosen to-day to constitute the new State Committee is an avowed supporter of Taggart, and Bernard Korbly, his choice for State Chairman, will be selected by unanimous vote.
abstract: Democratic organization controlled by Tom Taggart

headline: SEEKS TO NAME SPEAKER.; Mills Will Try to Unite Assemblymen on Candidate to Beat Hinman.
leadPara: Ogden L. Mills, Treasurer of the Republican County Committee and one of the leaders in the fight against Barnes within the Republican State organization, left for a tour of the State last night. In the course of his trip Mr. Mills will endeavor to unite behind one candidate for Speaker the Assemblymen-elect who are opposed to Barnes.
abstract: Ogden L. Mills will urge unity on candidate to oppose Hinman

headline: MINE OWNERS AFTER SECRETARY WILSON; Michigan Copper Men May Protest in Congress Against His Labor Utterances. CALUMET PANIC EXPLAINED Many Witnesses Deny That a Foe of the Strikers Gave the Alarm -Bullet Taken from Moyer's Back.
leadPara: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Reports reached here to-night that the mine owners in the Michigan copper region intended to protest through a resolution in Congress against comment made by William B. Wilson, Secretary of Labor, concerning labor conditions in the mines in various parts of the country.
abstract: Michigan copper mine owners may protest in Congress against his labor utterances

headline: SPEAKERSHIP FIGHT LOOKS LIKE A TIE; Bitterness in Republican Ranks May Cause a Long Delay in Assembly Organization. BARNES CANDIDATE WEAK Hinman Can Muster Only 32 Votes of a Necessary 76, up-State Leader Estimates.
leadPara: The caucus of the Republican Assemblymen-elect, at which their candidate for Speaker of the Assembly is to be selected, has been called for next Tuesday evening, and will be held in the Assembly Chamber at the Capitol. It is the desire of the organization leaders that it be held behind closed doors.
abstract: candidacy reported to be weak

headline: NOTEWORTHY EVENTS IN THE WORLD'S PROGRESS IN 1913; HEAVY MILITARY BUDGETS IN EUROPE Balkan Wars Also Result in Activity to Exploit Asia Minor Commercially. MEXICO OUR ONLY CLOUD Chronology of Activities, at Home and Abroad, by Governments, Institutions, and Individuals.
leadPara: THE year 1913 closes, having fulfilled few of the prophecies made twelve months ago. Bulgaria, which then loomed large in the Balkans, has been humiliated, but not by the Turk. One of the results of the fighting there has been gigantic war budgets for both Germany and France, with a sympathetic increase of the war budgets of the Netherlands and Belgium.
abstract: REVIEW for 1913 of Events, Accidents, Achievements, &c.
